organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation:
The decrease in gross planned spending is mainly explained by a reduction of Employment Insurance Benefits due to the impact of COVID-19 on the Employment Insurance Benefits.

The decrease in net planned spending and in full-time equivalents is mainly the result of temporary resources provided to address the Employment Insurance workload.
variance_explanation:
"The variance in gross spending is mainly due to actual spending of Employment Insurance (EI) benefits under the Part I of the Employment Insurance Act being lower than originally planned. This is largely explained by temporary measures such as common entrance requirements and simplification measures that were put in place in September 2021 and extended into fiscal year 2022 to 2023 to facilitate access to benefits but ended in September 2022.  In addition, at net the variance between planned and actual spending is mainly due to the $483 million credited to the account for EI Emergency Response Benefit (ERB) in fiscal year 2022 to 2023.

The variance between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) mainly reflects additional staff hired to process Employment Insurance claims as well as to improve call centre accessibility. "

variance_explanation:
"The variance between planned and actual spending is attributable to lower than anticipated capacity of third-party organizations delivering projects funded by the Opportunities Fund; and to delays in negotiations with organizations due to competing operational priorities that resulted from the significant increase in funding received in response to the pandemic.

No significant variance for FTEs."

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation:
The increase in planned spending is related to the expansion of the Canada Service Corps as per Budget 2019. Canada Service Corps has been delivering an increasing amount of grants and contributions since 2019-20. In 2022-23, it will deliver close to $82M in grants and contributions and will reach approximately $93M in grants and contributions in 2023-24 and for future years. The level of operating funds to deliver those payments will increase mostly in 2024-25.

The increase in full-time equivalents is associated with the increase in the level of operating funds to deliver the program.
variance_explanation:
"The variance between planned and actual spending is due to new projects starting later than anticipated, leaving excess funding available. 

No significant variance for FTEs."

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development

variance_explanation:
"The variance between planned and actual spending is due to setting up of agreements occurring late in the fiscal year leading to reduced program expenditures in the fiscal year ending March 31, 2023 following a Call for Proposals. 

The variance between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) is due to the department reallocating resources based on program operational requirements."

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation: The planned spending in 2022-23 and 2023-24 is higher than the 2024-25 figure because it includes COVID-19 funding that will end in 2023-24.
variance_explanation:
"The variance between planned and actual spending is primarily attributable to delays in launching the Skills for Success in-take processes, a longer than expected assessment period resulting from an unexpectedly high volume of applications received, and delays in negotiations with organizations; and delays in negotiations with organizations for the Women’s Employment Readiness Pilot Project due to competing operational priorities that resulted from the significant increase in funding received in response to the pandemic. 

No significant variance for FTEs."

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
program_name: Indigenous Skills and Employment Training (ISET) Program
variance_explanation:
"No significant variance between planned and actual spending.

The variance between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) is resulting from realignment of staffing to match Sub-Program Activity. This is due to implementation of new or adjusted processes given the reorientation of the ISET program within or emerging from a COVID environment. While there is minimal variance in overall personnel costs, there were adjustments to the complementarity of levels to support implementation needs reorientation during this transitional period."

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development

variance_explanation:
"The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly due to delays in launching projects following two Sectoral Workforce Solutions Program (SWSP) calls for proposals (CFP) that closed in March 2022. Subsequently, the start of related project activities was delayed to the fall/winter of 2022, allowing for an average of less than 6 months for expenditures. 

The variance between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) is due to delays in launching the SWSP, including the two CFPs, the limited pool of qualified candidates in a tight labour market, and the realignment of staffing priorities in response to emerging pressures.   
"

"

The end of this measure will result in a decrease in program expenditures moving forward. This measure affects the Canada Student Grants issued to students and the alternative payments made to non participating provinces and territories.
variance_explanation:
"The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by expected write-offs authorities not being included in the Departmental plan planned spending as they require Parliamentary approval through Supplementary Estimates during the fiscal year. As part of the Supplementary Estimates C, the Department accessed Vote 10c authorities to cover roughly $221 million in write-offs. The addition of the write-offs net of slightly lower than expected grant disbursements explain the variance between planned and actual spending.

No significant variance for FTEs."

planning_explanation: Variance is related to new funding received for the Support for Women Entrepreneurs program, the Canada Digital Adoption Program-Grow Your Business Online and the Small Business and Entrepreneurship Development Program as per Budget 2021. New funding was also received for the Black Entrepreneurship Program: Loan Fund and the Diverse and Inclusive Economy Program as per the Fall Economic Statement 2020.
variance_explanation: Variance primarily represents unused funding in the Canada Digital Adoption Program: Stream 1 program as a result of recipients' application and hiring processes.  Also reflected is unused funding in the Small Business and Entrepreneurship Development Program and the Women's Entrepreneurship Strategy as a result of extensive proposal assessments and contribution agreement negotiations with applicants.  Unused funding in all programs will be moved to future years.

planning_explanation: Variance is primarily related to new funding received for the Universal Broadband Fund and the Low Earth Orbit Satellite Capacity Fund. The increase in 2021-22 is offset by the winding down of several contribution programs, namely: Affordable Access Initiative, Accessible Technology Development program and the Digital Literacy Exchange Program, as well as the Connect to Innovate program for which funding ends in 2022-23.
variance_explanation: Variance primarily reflects unused funding in the Universal Broadband Fund due in part to the time required to assess proposals and negotiate contribution agreement with recipients for projects in 2022-23. In addition, many UBF applicants that have conditionally approved projects needed additional time to finalize their plans and events related to sensitive and complex project locations serving Indigenous communities.  Funding will be moved to future years to better align with anticipated projects cash flow requirements in order to meet connectivity objectives of 98% by 2026.  Also reflected is unused funding in the Connect to Innovate program and the Telesat Low Earth Orbit Satellite Capacity program. Unused funding in these two programs has been identified to be moved to future years to respect existing agreements and better align with anticipated cash flow requirements.

planning_explanation:
Variance is related to new funding received through Budget 2021, mainly under the Pan-Canadian Artificial Intelligence Strategy for the Canadian Institute for Advanced Research, the National Artificial Intelligence Institutes and for dedicated computing capacity in Artificial Intelligence. Budget 2021 also announced new funding under the Biomanufacturing and Life Sciences Strategy for Canada Foundation for Innovation, Stem Cell Network and adMare BioInnovations. 

These increases are offset by the winding down of funding under several programs such as the Digital Research Infrastructure Strategy, Post-Secondary Institutions Strategic Investment Fund,  CANARIE Inc, the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics and the Institute for Quantum Computing.
variance_explanation: Variance primarily represents unused funding by the Digital Research Alliance recipient under the Digital Research Infrastructure Strategy.  The recipient required additional time to develop critical governance documents required to support the implementation of major projects.  Also reflected is unused funding under the Canada Foundation for Innovation from successive federal budgets, for which associated funding required a realignment with CFI's anticipated cashflow requirements.  Unused funding in both programs has been moved to future years.

planning_explanation: Variance is related to funding received through Budget 2021 under the Pan-Canadian Artificial Intelligence Strategy as well as the National Quantum Strategy for the Innovation Superclusters Initiative and Innovative Solutions Canada.  Budget 2021 also announced new funding for the new Net Zero Accelerator initiative to support Canada’s Strengthened Climate Plan's third pillar, Building Canada's Clean Industrial Advantage. The Fall Economic Statement 2020 announced funding over five years, starting in 2021-22, to support innovative, intellectual property-rich firms in facing the challenges presented by COVID-19, as well as foreign take-overs and potentially mitigate the loss of Canadian jobs. Also stemming from the Fall Economic Statement 2020 is new funding over seven years, starting in 2021-22, to support Sanofi Pasteur Ltd.'s vaccine manufacturing facility. The funding profiles for the Strategic Innovation Fund, the Innovative Superclusters Initiative and the Cyber Security Innovation Network have been adjusted to meet actual requirements and timelines of the program by moving funding, from 2021-22 to future years.
variance_explanation: Variance primarily represents unused funding in the Strategic Innovation Fund and the Innovation Superclusters Initiative as a result of the lingering effects of the pandemic.  Funding will be moved to future years to allow recipients to complete contracted projects, and to align the funding profile with the cashflow requirements of these programs.  Also reflected is unused funding under the Canada Digital Adoption Program: Stream 2 as a result of slower than anticipated program uptake.  Unused funding will be moved to future years to better align the program funding profile with anticipated demand.

planning_explanation: Variance primarily reflects anticipated future claim payments under the Canada Small Business Financing Program. These adjustments are made annually to reflect updated claim forecasts incorporating changes in the use of the program by lenders as well as ongoing changes in loan loss experiences.
variance_explanation: Variance between the planned and actual spending under the CSBFA is primarily the result of an overestimation of claim payments on defaulted loans.  With the economic downturn associated with the COVID-19 pandemic, claims for loss submissions resulting from defaulted loans were expected to increase significantly.  The claim for loss submissions, however, did not materialize to the extent predicted resulting in lower than expected claim payment expenses for 2022-23.

planning_explanation: Variance between 2021-22 and future years is related to funding received from the Department of National Defence for the Defence Procurement Strategy.
variance_explanation: The variance represents funding that was allocated to priorities in other activities.

planning_explanation: Variance between 2021-22 and future years is related to existing funding allocated for the implementation of the Digital Credentials, Identity and Business Information Sharing in fiscal year 2021-22 only.
variance_explanation: N/A - variance is less than 10%

planning_explanation: Variance between 2021-22 and future years is related to the New Generation of Wireless Technology (5G). The funding profile has been adjusted to meet actual requirements and timelines of the program.
variance_explanation: Variance represents unused funding as a result of continued pandemic-related procurement delays related to the New Generation Wireless Technology - 5G initiative.  Funding has been moved to future years.

planning_explanation: Variance is related to new funding received for the Recapitalization of the Sustainable Development Technology Fund. The funding profile has been adjusted, to meet actual requirements and timelines of the program, by moving funding from 2021-22 to future years.
variance_explanation: Variance primarily reflects unused funding in the Sustainable Development Technology Fund as a result of lingering effects of the pandemic.  It has been moved to future years to reflect their financial forecasting model which was revised following a recent review of historical data and updated assumptions.

planning_explanation: Variance is related to the fluctuations in the estimated amount drawn down from Canadian Intellectual Property Office (CIPO) accumulated Surplus.
variance_explanation: Variance reflects the lower than anticipated drawdown on CIPO's revolving fund as they generated more revenue in 2022-23 than planned.

planning_explanation: Variance is related to new funding announced in Budget 2021 to enhance competition enforcement and promotion in the digital economy. Stable funding in 2024-25 and beyond will allow the Competition Bureau to exercise its mandate to pursue investigations that have grown in number and complexity over the past decade.

variance_explanation: Variance reflects additional funding accessed in-year. The unused portion will be moved to 2023-24 to allow recipients to complete and maximize project activities and benefits as part of the National Tourism Priorities Stream.

planning_explanation: Variance is related to funding received through Budget 2021 for CanCode 3.0, Mitacs Inc., Digital Skills for Youth, Computers for Schools Intern program and Upskilling for Industry Initiative. The variance in planned versus actual spending is mainly attributable to an increase in legal services provided, mainly on litigation files, which led to an increase in revenues recognized that more than offset the increase in spending from a net perspective.

planning_explanation: The variance in planned spending is explained by the sunset of temporary funding received over a five-year period (2019-20 to 2023-24) for Bringing Innovation to Regulations through the implementation of two regulatory review roadmaps for the agri-food and aquaculture sector and the health and biosciences sector.

variance_explanation: The variance in planned versus actual FTEs is mainly related to additional resources to support policy work on Indigenous-related files as announced in Budgets 2021 and 2022 such as: the UN Declaration Act Implementation Secretariat, Reconciliation Secretariat and the Office of the Special Interlocutor. Some of the workforce related to these initiatives was not included in planned FTEs due to the timing of securing these resources and their inclusion into the Main Estimates.

planning_explanation: The variance in planned spending is mainly explained by temporary funding received in 2022-23 for Criminal Legal Aid to ensure that jurisdictions have the capacity to meet increased demand for criminal legal aid resulting from COVID-19, and are able to further implement technological innovations that have become a requirement throughout the pandemic.
variance_explanation:
The variance in planned versus actual spending is mainly explained by increased contribution spending resulting from additional funding received during the year to maintain federal support for immigration and refugee legal aid services, as announced in Budget 2022.

The variance in planned versus actual FTEs is explained by the retirement of two employees in 2022-23 whose positions are yet to be filled.

The variance in planned versus actual spending is explained by the fact that some provinces/territories are not yet ready to implement the Contraventions Act Regime and therefore did not incur expenditures as anticipated. The negotiations and progress depend largely on the priorities, and therefore capacity, of the provinces and territories. The funds will be completely committed once all jurisdictions have signed agreements.

The variance in planned versus actual FTEs is explained by the departure of an employee whose position is yet to be filled.

The variance in planned versus actual spending is explained by increased contribution spending resulting from additional funding received during the year to expand access to Drug Treatment Courts, as announced in Budget 2021.

planning_explanation: The variance in planned spending is explained by the sunset of temporary funding received over a three-year period (2020-21 to 2022-23) to respond to the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls’ Final Report: Reclaiming Power and Place. More specifically, the contributions funding to support Family Information Liaison Units and community-based services.
variance_explanation: The variance in planned versus actual FTEs is explained by the realignment of a full-time equivalent between activities to better reflect Departmental priorities.

The variance in planned versus actual spending is mainly explained by lower uptake by provinces/territories of contributions funding to support supervision services for parenting time in cases of separation and divorce (funding under the National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence). In addition, there was lower uptake by recipients of contributions funding for former Bill C-78 (An Act to amend the Divorce Act, the Family Orders and Agreements Enforcement Assistance Act and the Garnishment, Attachment and Pension Diversion Act and to make consequential amendments to another Act) and provinces not accessing their maximum funding available.

planning_explanation: The variance in planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary funding received over a three-year period (2021-22 to 2023-24) to (1) improve access to justice for Indigenous people and address systemic barriers in the criminal justice system, and (2) improve access to justice through Indigenous engagement on justice-related issues and the Reconciliation Secretariat.

The variance in planned spending is explained by the sunset of temporary funding received over a five-year period (2019-20 to 2023-24) to (1) support renewed legal relationships with Indigenous peoples by supporting Indigenous law initiatives across Canada (Truth and Reconciliation Commission Call to Action no. 50), and (2) provide legal support and awareness to address sexual harassment in the workplace.
variance_explanation: The variance in planned versus actual FTEs is explained by an increase in one full-time equivalent needed to deliver new projects within the Justice Partnership and Innovation program, as well as one temporarily vacant position, which was excluded from planned spending and staffed afterwards.
The variance in planned versus actual spending is mainly explained by lower spending on operating and maintenance expenditures.

The variance in planned versus actual spending is explained by permanent Budget 2021 reductions included in planned spending (namely travel reductions and permanent reallocation of resources to Shared Services Canada for IT services). These reductions were temporarily allocated to this program in 2022-23 until more information became available and reductions were reallocated to the proper programs. The remainder of the variance is mainly explained by personnel expenditure increases due to the growth in the workforce with regards to various departmental and governmental priorities, such as the Anti-Racism and Anti-Discrimination Secretariat and internal services support to the Office of the Special Interlocutor.

planning_explanation: All legal services resources and expenditures for the Department of Justice Canada are reported under its Legal Services Core Responsibility.
variance_explanation: All legal services resources and expenditures for the Department of Justice Canada are reported under its Legal Services Core Responsibility.

The variance in planned versus actual spending is mainly explained by increases in personnel expenditures related to the growth in the workforce in response to an increase in staffing requests across the Department, to the new development program for law practitioners, and continued investments into the Stabilization and Modernization of the Pay System.

The variance in planned versus actual spending is mainly explained by expenditure increases related to in-year funding of information technology projects and internal pressures, which are excluded from planned spending, such as: investments to enhance connectivity, improve software services to law practitioners, support Cloud services, support applications deployed to enable hybrid work, and increased purchasing of computer equipment.

The variance in planned versus actual spending is explained by an increase in personnel expenditures for new employees needed to support higher demand for personnel security screening requests, and by the in-year funding of real property projects, which are excluded from planned spending, such as modernizing the electronic physical security equipment for the protection of the Department's personnel, assets and information.

The variance in planned versus actual FTEs is explained by an increase in demand for personnel security screening requests, which has led to additional hiring.

planning_explanation: Not applicable - Due to low materiality, the resources and expenditures for Material Management Services are now aligned and reported under Acquisition Management Services.
variance_explanation: Not applicable - Due to low materiality, the resources and expenditures for Material Management Services are now aligned and reported under Acquisition Management Services.
The variance in planned versus actual FTEs is explained by an increase in operational requirements related to acquisition management, which has led to additional hiring.

planning_explanation:
Planned spending in Statutory authorities is increasing from 2022-23 to 2024-25, mainly as a result of the Atlantic Offshore Accounts.
Statutory payment obligations under these accords are largely related to royalty transfers to the province of Newfoundland and Labrador which are driven by oil and gas prices, production levels and anticipated corporate income taxes related to offshore
operations. The planned spending is based on the Department's economic modeling forecasts prepared in the fall of 2021.
variance_explanation:
The decrease in spending is primarily due to the difference between forecasted royalty transfers compared to actual royalty transfers recorded. This variance  is the result of fluctuations in the price of oil, changes in production, the timing of sales, forfeitures, as well as actual Corporate Income Tax transfers versus forecasts.
FTEs: No variance explanation required.

variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2022-23 is primarily the result of resources required to support the Cyber Security Cooperation Program due to timing of program approval and administration. FTEs: Variance ≤ 10%.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding and planned FTEs for Crime Prevention from 2022-23 to 2023-24 is primarily attributable to the maturation of the Initiative to Take Action Against Gun and Gang Violence, which is being complemented by a new $250 million investment to establish the Building Safer Communities Fund to continue to respond to the call to combat gun and gang violence.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2022-23 is primarily the result of a lapse under the Building Safer Communities Fund due to unforeseen delays in launch and startup. Furthermore, some municipalities spent less than originally forecasted but are still seeking full funding allocation over the term of their projects. The intention is to transfer this funding for use in future fiscal years. The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents in 2022-23 is primarily the result of delays in planned staffing due to increased turnover.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2022-23 is primarily the result of new funding received through the Supplementary Estimates to support the National Capital Extraordinary Policing Costs program, for the Memorial Grant Program for First Responders, to support the design and development of a buyback program for prohibited assault-style firearms and for extraordinary costs related to Ambassador Bridge blockade. The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents in 2022-23 is primarily due to new salary funding received through the Supplementary Estimates to support the design and development of a buyback program for prohibited assault-style firearms.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding and planned FTEs for Serious and Organized Crime from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is primarily attributable to the expiry of funding for the Anti-Money Laundering Action, Coordination and Enforcement (ACE) Team and the National Strategy to Combat Human Trafficking in 2023-24, and a decrease in funding levels for the initiative to build capacity to address drug impaired driving in Canada.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2022-23 is primarily the result of the Biology Casework Analysis Contribution Program (BCACP) planned spending being presented under the Corrections program inventory. The actuals were realigned to be presented under the Serious and Organized Crime program inventory. The variance is further exacerbated by new funding received through the Supplementary Estimates to protect children from online sexual exploitation and to strengthen Canada's anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist financing regime but offset by a transfer to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) to address drug-impaired driving as well as a lapse under the Drug Impaired Driving Initiative within the Contribution Program to Combat Serious and Organized Crime (CPCSOC). The intention is to transfer some of this lapsed funding for use in future fiscal years. FTEs: No Variance.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2022-23 is primarily the result of Employee Benefit Plan allocation between programs inventories. FTEs: Variance ≤ 10%.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The increase in planned funding for Indigenous Policing from 2022-23 to 2023-24 is primarily attributable to the increase in funding to support Indigenous policing and community safety.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2022-23 is primarily the result of a transfer to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police for the First Nations Community Policing Service offset by new funding received through the Supplementary Estimates for the First Nations and Inuit Policing Program and the First Nations and Inuit Policing Facilities program. Furthermore, there are lapses under the First Nations and Inuit Policing Program and the First Nations and Inuit Policing Facilities program due to project delays. The intention is to transfer the full amount of this lapsed funding for use in future fiscal years. The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents in 2022-23 is due to the establishment of the new Indigenous Affairs Branch and the FTEs required to staff the branch.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The increase in planned funding for Corrections from 2022-23 to 2023-24 is primarily attributable to an increase in funding levels for the expansion of the Aboriginal Community Safety Planning Initiative and the Record Suspension Program to reform the pardons process.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2022-23 is primarily the result of the Biology Casework Analysis Contribution Program planned spending and additional funding received through the Supplementary Estimates being presented under the Corrections program inventory. The actuals were realigned and are now presented under the Serious and Organized Crime program inventory. FTEs: Variance ≤ 10%.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness

The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents in 2022-23 is primarily the result of new salary funding received through the Supplementary Estimates to advance the Canada’s Flood Risk Plan.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness

variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2022-23 is primarily the result of a funding transfer for use in future fiscal years for the relocation and accommodations for the Government Operations Centre due to unforeseen project delays. organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
variance_explanation:
Actual spending exceeded planned spending by approximately $23.8 M. This gap is explained by higher spending than planned in Quebec economic development program. In 2020-2021, CED granted its clients a moratorium on the reimbursement of repayable contributions as a measure to mitigate the Covid-19 pandemic. These reimbursements being reinvested two years later, CED thus shows a shortfall in 2022-2023 in its expenses planned at the start of the year. In order to limit the impacts of the moratorium on regular programming, repayable contributions from 2023-2024 have been brought forward.

Additionally, funding for the International Sustainability Standards Board, a new initiative, was provided during the fiscal year.

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
planning_explanation:
The significant decrease in funding and FTEs over the fiscal years is primarily due to the termination of several temporary and targeted initiatives in the coming fiscal years.  
Among others, as of March 31, 2023, the following initiatives will end:
- Tourism Relief Fund
- Major Festivals and Events Support Initiative
- Canadian Community Revitalization Fund
- Regional Infrastructure Development Initiative 
Also, as of March 31, 2024, the following initiatives will be terminated:
- Jobs and Growth Fund
- Aerospace Regional Recovery Initiative
variance_explanation:
Actual spending was lower than planned spending by approximately $64.6 M. This gap is mainly explained by the postponement of several projects for one year following the extension of economic recovery initiatives. 
Here are the initiatives for which funds have been carried forward from 2022-2023 to 2023-2024: the Major Festivals and Events Support Initiative, the Canadian Community Revitalization Fund, the Aerospace Regional Recovery Initiative and the initiative for the development of regional economic infrastructure in Quebec. These initiatives were postponed since several projects were unable to materialize in 2022-2023 due to lack of labor, delays in supply chains and inflation.

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
planning_explanation:
The variance between the 2022-2023 and 2023-2024 projected budgets is primarily due to the reinvestment of revenue from repayable contributions from our clients that are not included as of April 1, 2023, as approvals have not been obtained at the time of writing.  

Also, the Innovation and Skills Plan, which is a temporary initiative, ends on March 31, 2023.
variance_explanation: CED is constantly adapting to the changing economic context, regional needs and government priorities. We spent slightly less than expected. Funds were therefore reallocated where the needs were greatest.

planning_explanation:
**Planned spending**
Planned spending reflects the repayment to the revolving fund authorities for investments made in 2019–2020. Repayment is planned over five years and began in 2021–2022. In 2022–2023 and future years, new capital investments will allow the NFB to implement the technology required to connect virtually across all NFB offices and facilities, and to adopt the optimal technological tools for creating audiovisual content at a distance. Financing will stemfrom drawdowns on the revolving fund authorities.

**FTEs**
Audiovisual productions benefited from accelerating the timeline of the 2021–2025 Technology Plan, which allowed creators to work and collaborate on their projects remotely. This technological transformation resulted in minimal interruptions to audiovisual production activities during the pandemic. The implementation of this infrastructure and these new workflows and systems will continue to improve as the Technology Plan is deployed.
Human resources levels reflect current operational needs.
variance_explanation:
The increase in actual spending versus planned spending is mostly due to funds carried-in from prior year, as well as funds received for critical operating requirements. Spending also includes retroactive payments for the economic increase in executives’ salaries. Funding for technology investments was drawn from the Main authorities, therefore no drawdowns were required for capital acquisitions from the revolving fund.
The decrease in human resources dedicated to audiovisual production reflects the changes made to the NFB’s programming structure and the time required to hire staff to implement them. The new structure will enable the NFB to define its strategic vision for programming, cover its territory more effectively, develop regional talent and enhance expertise in its studios.

program_name: Distribution of works and audience engagement
planning_explanation:
**Spending**
In 2022-23 and future years, new capital investments will allow the NFB to implement the technology required to connect virtually across all NFB offices and facilities, as well as the optimal technological tools for the distribution of audiovisual content at a distance. Financing stems from drawdowns on the revolving fund authorities which are more significant in 2022-23.

**FTEs**
In 2022-23 and future years, the NFB will continue to explore new distribution channels, including digital platforms supporting VR, app stores and public venues hosting virtual experiences.
variance_explanation:
The increase in actual spending is due to several factors, including distribution activities returning to pre-pandemic levels and funds received for critical operating requirements. Spending also includes retroactive payments for the economic increase in executives’ salaries. Funding for technology investments was drawn from the Main authorities, therefore no drawdowns were required for capital acquisitions from the revolving fund.
The number of full-time equivalents includes resources to support digital distribution efforts.

program_name: Promotion of works and National Film Board outreach
planning_explanation: Activities related to promotion of works and NFB outreach are expected to resume as the impact of the pandemic subsides, and remain stable in future years.
variance_explanation:
The increase in actual spending is due to greater efforts being devoted to promotional and outreach activities, as well as funds received for critical operating requirements. Spending also includes retroactive payments for the economic increase in executives’ salaries.
The number of full-time equivalents assigned to the NFB’s promotion and outreach has increased, especially in connection with project launches and digital platform operations.

program_name: Preservation, conservation and digitization of works
planning_explanation: Digitization and preservation activities will focus on restoring the image component of digitized films in the NFB’s active collection.
variance_explanation:
The increase in actual spending was partly financed by funds received for critical operating requirements. Spending also includes retroactive payments for the economic increase in executives’ salaries.
The decrease in human resources is mainly due to a greater proportion of technical services allocated to the distribution and promotion of works.

planning_explanation:
**Planned Spending**
Planned spending expenditures include ongoing needs for services that support program delivery in the organization.
In 2022–2023 and future years, new capital investments will allow the NFB to implement the technology required to connect virtually across all NFB offices and facilities. These investments will also permit the organization to develop an information-management strategy that allows for decision making based on reliable data that’s easily accessible through a centralized portal.
Financing will stem from drawdowns on the revolving fund authorities.

**FTEs**
Ensuring the health and safety of its staff and collaborators is the NFB’s top priority. A multidisciplinary team is actively managing the response to COVID-19 through the implementation of a remote work policy, regular communication about and implementation of
evolving health measures, and the production of reports on the impact of the pandemic. Moreover, several initiatives are taking place in order to develop the organization’s information management technologies, in particular by implementing a business intelligence system to improve decision-making.
variance_explanation:
Actual spending is higher than planned results due to continued support for projects aimed at streamlining business processes and improving the organization’s compliance with government policies and directives. The increased level of expenditures was partly financed with funds received for critical operating requirements. Spending also includes retroactive payments for the economic increase in executives’ salaries.
The number of full-time equivalents dedicated to internal services decreased temporarily as a result of delays in hiring staff to help renew and reinforce the teams, in particular to support the NFB’s operational processes and strengthen its compliance with government policies and directives.

core_responsibility: Record Suspension/Pardon and Expungement Decisions/Clemency Recommendations
program_name: Record Suspension/Pardon and Expungement Decisions/Clemency Recommendations
planning_explanation: The variance is the result of a reform in the pardon process that took place in 2021-22. The PBC’s Record Suspension/Pardon core responsibility is now funded in part with revenues from a lower service fee. The fee was $657.77 and as of January 1, 2022, it has been reduced to $50.00 in accordance with the _Pardon Service Fees Order._
variance_explanation: The lapse can be explained with delayed planned staffing in the Record Suspension and Expungement Decisions/Clemency core responsibility and the authority to reprofile $1.7M to future years caused by delay in the renewal design of Pardon and Record Suspension System (PARSS).

The variance for Internal Services (i.e., actual spending greater than planned) is in large part due to the newly negotiated Master Service Agreement with Correctional Service Canada for the provision of IM/IT Services. The FTE increase is attributable to the need for additional capacity for IT, compensation, and financial services.

Supply chain issues reported in previous fiscal years have continued to be observed throughout 2022-23 impacting Infrastructure Canada's delivery of programs. The variance is primarily within two programs: the Investing in Canada Infrastructure Canada Program (ICIP) and the New Building Canada Fund under the National and Regional Projects stream.

core_responsibility: Public Infrastructure and Communities Investment Oversight and Delivery

variance_explanation: The variance in spending is primarily due to Infrastructure Canada investing in resources needed to perform activities in support of High Frequency Rail, which was announced in Budget 2022.

The variance in FTEs is due to additional capacity needed to launch intake processes and evaluate processes to successfully deliver the new, mostly merit-based programming announced in the 2020 Fall Economic Statement and Budget 2021.
Alignment of funding is currently under review for Major Bridges Oversight for future years.

In October 2021, the responsibilities of the Homelessness Policy Directorate was transferred from Employment and Social Development Canada (ESDC) to Infrastructure Canada (INFC). As of April 1, 2023, INFC has full responsibility for the delivery of the program, however, a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was created in fiscal year 2022-23 for ESDC to continue to support the Reaching Home program through the transition.

core_responsibility: Public Infrastructure, Communities and Rural Economic Development Policy

core_responsibility: Public Infrastructure, Communities and Rural Economic Development Policy

variance_explanation: The variance in spending is due to the mandated transfer of the Housing and Homelessness portfolio from Employment and Social Development Canada effective October 26, 2021. Infrastructure Canada continued to onboard the portfolio and related responsibilities in 2022-23.
The variance in FTEs is primarily due to an increase in oversight capacity to support the mandated transfer of the Housing and Homelessness portfolio.
The variance in spending is due to Infrastructure Canada investing in resources needed to successfully deliver on programming approved through the 2020 Fall Economic Statement and Budget 2021.
Services are rendered by the Department of Justice and as such, INFC has no FTEs associated with Legal.
The variance in spending & FTEs is due to Infrastructure Canada investing in its human resources function to provide the support needed given the department's growth since 2021.
The variance in spending & FTEs is due to the department investing in its financial management function to support the department's growth and delivery of its expanded programming.

The variance in spending & FTEs is primarily a result of supporting a growing departmental client base and a need to support growing program delivery requirements. Furthermore, the mandated introduction of the Chief Data Officer function contributed to the variance in 2022-23.

The variance in spending & FTEs is due to additional investments in hardware, software and staff required to accommodate the increase in FTEs and continued growth in programs, as well as to support the transition to a hybrid working environment.
The variance in spending is attributable to delays and cancellations in planned procurement spending.

The variance in spending is related to Space Optimization projects. While the department's space utilization has not changed with the increase in resources, the space was adapted to accommodate greater capacity and taking into consideration a hybrid work model.
The variance in spending is due to a realignment of resources to support departmental priorities. The variance in FTEs is nominal in the broader context.

organization: Office of the Chief Electoral Officer
planning_explanation:
The fluctuation in planned spending over these fiscal years is mainly due to the closing of the 44th general election and investing in electoral services modernization.

The fluctuation in planned full-time equivalents over these fiscal years is mainly due to the closing of the 44th general election.
variance_explanation:
The difference of $39.2 million includes some $30 million that was incorrectly planned for in Voting Services instead of Field Management. This error resulted from the fact that 2022–23 was the first year that these two programs were separated under this new program structure. The effective net difference of $9.2 million is primarily a result of postponing some planned preparation activities for the 45th general election.

The difference of 135 full-time equivalents includes some 70 full-time equivalents that were incorrectly planned for in Voting Services instead of Field Management. This error resulted from the fact that 2022–23 was the first year that these two programs were separated under this new program structure. The effective difference of 65 full-time equivalents is largely explained by the same reasons stated above.

organization: Office of the Chief Electoral Officer
planning_explanation:
The fluctuation in planned spending over these fiscal years is mainly due to the closing of the 44th general election and investing in electoral services modernization.

The fluctuation in planned full-time equivalents over these fiscal years is mainly due to the closing of the 44th general election.
variance_explanation:
The difference of $24.3 million includes some $30 million that was incorrectly planned for in Voting Services instead of Field Management. This error resulted from the fact that 2022–23 was the first year that these two programs were separated under this new program structure. The effective net difference of $5.7 million is primarily a result of postponing some planned preparation activities for the 45th general election as well as the reprofile of some investments in digital transformation priorities. On the other hand, there is the inclusion of the cost to conduct a by-election, which was not part of the agency’s Main Estimates.

The difference of 90 full-time equivalents includes some 70 full-time equivalents that were incorrectly planned for in Voting Services instead of Field Management. This error resulted from the fact that 2022–23 was the first year that these two programs were separated under this new program structure. The effective difference of 20 full-time equivalents is primarily the result of closing activities, including those of the electoral material distribution centre, for the 44th general election.

variance_explanation: Actual FTEs for the Heritage Places Establishment Program is 46 FTEs or 32% lower than the 2022-23 planned FTEs.  This variance is primarily due to staffing delays.

core_responsibility: Protecting and Presenting Canada's Natural and Cultural Heritage
planning_explanation: The decrease in 2024-25 planned spending is primarily due to the sunset of funding in 2023-24 for Parks Canada to implement the Wood Buffalo National Park World Heritage Site Action Plan.
variance_explanation: Actual spending for the Heritage Places Conservation is $35.9 million or 11% lower than the 2022-23 planned spending. The variance is primarily due to changes in planned activities, and the resulting transfer of funds from 2022-23 to 2023-24 for conservation initiatives such as Enhanced Nature Legacy, Wood Buffalo Action Plan, Imminent Threats to Wood Bison, Implementation of Rights and Reconciliation Agreements in Atlantic Canada, Wildfire Resilience as well as Federal Contaminated Sites Action Plan.

core_responsibility: Protecting and Presenting Canada's Natural and Cultural Heritage
program_name: Heritage Places Promotion and Public Support
planning_explanation: The decrease in 2023-24 planned spending is primarily due to the sunset of funding in 2022-23 for: Parks Canada’s advertising initiatives related to the Visitation and Conservation National Campaign; the implementation of Truth and Reconciliation Commission Call to Action 79; and the grant funding for the implementation of Inuit Impact and Benefit Agreement related to the establishment and operation of the Wrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Site.
variance_explanation: Actual spending for the Heritage Places Promotion and Public Support Program is $15.5 million or 24% higher than the 2022-23 planned spending.  This variance is primarily due to the timing of new funding received after the planning exercise for the Trans Canada Trail and investments in trail connections to Rouge National Urban Park, Learn-to camp initiative as well as the advertising program.

core_responsibility: Protecting and Presenting Canada's Natural and Cultural Heritage
planning_explanation:
The decrease in 2023-24 planned spending is primarily due to the sunset of funding (reprofiled amount to 2022-23) for B2019 Measures Supporting Capital Assets in Canada’s National Parks, National Marine Conservation Areas and National Historic Sites.  The Agency is continuing its effort in developing a long-term plan aimed at securing sustainable funding for the management and maintenance of its capital assets.

The decrease in planned full-time equivalents is primarily due to the one year funding for 2022-23 for the Youth Employment and Skills Strategy.
variance_explanation: Actual spending for the Visitor Experience is $95.4 million or 28% higher than the 2022-23 planned spending. This variance is primarily due to additional funding carried over from the previous fiscal year and timing of new funding received after the planning exercise mainly related to funding for Investments in Assets to Support Transition to Long-term Asset Sustainability, as well as funding to restore damaged infrastructure from Hurricane Fiona at sites in Atlantic Canada and the province of Quebec.

core_responsibility: Protecting and Presenting Canada's Natural and Cultural Heritage
program_name: Heritage Canals, Highways and Townsites Management
planning_explanation: The decrease in 2023-24 planned spending is primarily due to the sunset of funding (reprofiled amount to 2022-23) for B2019 Measures Supporting Capital Assets in Canada’s National Parks, National Marine Conservation Areas and National Historic Sites.  The Agency is continuing its effort in developing a long-term plan aimed at securing sustainable funding for the management and maintenance of its capital assets.
variance_explanation: Actual spending for the Heritage Canals, Highways and Townsite Management program is $48.0 million or 62% higher than 2022-23 planned spending.  This variance is primarily due to timing of new funding received after the planning exercise mainly related to funding for Investments in Assets to Support Transition to Long-term Asset Sustainability.

Actual spending for the Management and Oversight sub-program is $18.9 million or 96% higher than 2022-23 planned spending.  This variance is primarily due to additional funds received after the planning exercise, mainly related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program. 

Actual FTEs for the Management and Oversight sub-program are 82 FTEs or 51% higher than planned FTEs in 2022-23. This variance is primarily due to additional funds received after the planning exercise, mainly related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment Program.

Actual spending for the Communication sub-program is $0.6 million or 13% higher than 2022-23 planned spending. This variance is primarily due to additional funds received after the planning exercise, mainly related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.

Actual FTEs for the Communications sub-program are 6 FTEs or 15% higher than planned FTEs in 2022-23.  This variance is primarily due to additional funds funding received after the planning exercise, mainly related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.
Actual spending for the Legal sub-program is $0.5 million or 12% lower than 2022-23 planned spending. This variance is due to legal services requirements being lower than what was planned.

Actual spending for the Human Resources Management sub-program is $7.3 million or 27% higher than 2022-23 planned spending. This variance is primarily due to internal reallocations to address funding priorities as well as additional funds received after the planning exercise, mainly related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.

Actual spending for the Financial Management sub-program is $12.5 million or 74% higher than 2022-23 planned spending.  This variance is primarily due to additional resources required to support financial management modernization as part of the implementation of one-year appropriation and two-vote structure, and preparation toward accrual-based budgeting as well as additional funds received after the planning exercise, mainly related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.

Actual FTEs for the Financial Management sub-program are 74 FTEs or 52% higher than planned FTEs in 2022-23.  This variance is primarily due to additional resources required to support financial management modernization as part of the implementation of one-year appropriation and two-vote structure, and preparation toward accrual-based budgeting, as well as additional funds received after the planning exercise, mainly related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.

Actual spending for the Information Management sub-program is $1.9 million or 29% higher than 2022-23 planned spending. This variance is primarily due to internal reallocations to address funding priorities such as building a digital future.

Actual spending for the Information Technology sub-program is $5.2 million or 62% higher than 2022-23 planned spending. This variance is primarily due to internal reallocations to address funding priorities such as the federal employees return to the workplace and building a digital future.

Actual spending for the Real Property sub-program is $3.5 million or 37% higher than 2022-23 planned spending. This variance is primarily due to additional funds received after the planning exercise related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.

Actual FTEs for the Real Property sub-program are 29 FTEs or 46% higher than planned FTEs in 2022-23.  This variance is primarily due to additional funds received after the planning exercise related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.

Actual spending for the Materiel Management sub-program is $0.03 million or 13% higher than 2022-23 planned spending.  This variance is primarily due to additional funds received after the planning exercise related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program. 

Actual FTEs for the Materiel Management sub-program are 1 FTE or 50% higher than planned FTEs in 2022-23.  This variance is primarily due to additional funds received after the planning exercise related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.

Actual spending for the Acquisition sub-program is $1.1 million or 26% higher than 2022-23 planned spending. This variance is primarily due to additional funds received after the planning exercise related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.

Actual FTEs for the Acquisition sub-program are 20 FTEs or 56% higher than planned FTEs in 2022-23. This variance is primarily due to additional funds received after the planning exercise related to capacity funding to support the Asset Investment program.

Planned spending in 2022-23 was higher than Actual spending largely due to a lapse of funding for the Special Purpose Allotment (SPA) to conduct Public Hearings. The SPA can only be used to cover the costs of public hearings, such as external legal counsel and expert witnesses, etc. For purposes of forecasting Planned Spending, it is necessary to assume that the entire SPA funding will be spent because these expenditures are dependent on the number of hearings, and the length and complexity of the hearings held, which are difficult to predict. In 2022-23, the SPA was $4,463,360 and the PMPRB only spent $396,067, a difference of $4,067,293. Any unspent amount is returned to the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Staff departures contributed to the difference in Planned and Actual FTEs, along with difficulties and delays in hiring replacements.

Spending Variance 
The variance for the spending is mainly resulting from a reallocation of spending between program activities and a few unanticipated departures and difficulty to staff.

Spending Variance 
The Public Service Employment Act (PSEA) changes cost was not included in the opening budget, which was approximately 1.4 million. Attrition was also lower than average for 2022−23.

FTE Variance 
The variance for the FTE is mainly resulting from a increase in indeterminate employees, related to the PSEA review implementation.

Spending Variance 
The spending variance is mainly due to salary rate revisions and an increase in staffing indeterminate positions. There was also an increase in spending for professional and special services delivered to the Public Service Commission of Canada by other government departments, for management consulting and legal services, and for acquiring computer equipment.

As delays amid on-going negotiations between Canada and the Europe Union (led by Global Affairs and Innovation, Science and Economic Development) continue, other measures were considered to sustain Canadian participation in Horizon Europe projects while discussions are ongoing.
