planning_explanation: Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for the delivery of ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources. Also reflected in all three years are planned resources for new initiatives from Budget 2021.
variance_explanation:
The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of an increase in resources for new initiatives from Budget 2021 and 2022 and other departmental organizations. These initiatives include Clean Technology Data Strategy, Intellectual Property Commercialization in the Higher Education Sector Survey, advancing a circular economy for plastics in Canada and the Federal Action Plan to Strengthen Internal Trade. 
Also contributing to the increase are internal investments approved through the agency's Integrated Strategic Planning Process.

planning_explanation: Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for the delivery of ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources. Also reflected in all three years are planned resources for new initiatives from Budget 2021 for which funding slightly decreases from 2022–23 to 2023–24 and remains relatively the same in 2024-25.

Voted spending peaked in 2021-22 when the 2021 Census of Population and 2021 Census of Agriculture were conducted and wind down thereafter. This pattern is typical due to the cyclical nature of the Census Program. Funding for the 2026 Census of Population and the 2026 Census of Agriculture has not yet been approved which amplifies the decrease in the overall Census program funding.
variance_explanation: The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of a reprofile of funds from 2020-21 and 2021-22 to 2022-23 in order to  successfully close out the final years of the 2021 Census cycle.

planning_explanation:
Statistics Canada is funded by two sources: direct parliamentary appropriations and cost-recovery activities. Statistics Canada has the authority to generate $120 million annually in respendable revenue, related to two streams: statistical surveys and related services, and custom requests and workshops. A large portion of this respendable revenue comes from federal departments to fund specific statistical projects.

Planned net budgetary spending represents statutory funding attributed to the program.
variance_explanation: The net spending for this program is related to non-respendable items such as the Employee Benefit Plan.  An increase in resources due to additional work associated with extra demands following the pandemic and the 2021 Census contributed to the increase in actual versus planned full-time equivalents.

planning_explanation:
Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for the delivery of ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources. Also reflected in all three years are planned resources for new initiatives from Budget 2021. 

Planned resources include funding related to the Investment Planning cycle.
variance_explanation:
The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of salary price increases, retroactive pay and other payments from the ratification of collective agreements. Also, funding was carried forward from 2021-22 allowing the agency to meet the needs of its cyclical programs and to invest in its integrated strategic plans.
The increases are partially offset by budget carried forward to 2023-24, as well as internal investments approved through the agency's Integrated Strategic Planning Process.
The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of an internal realignment between Communications services and Centres of Expertise program.
Legal service expenditures are difficult to plan as they are incurred as needed.
The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of an internal realignment between Human Resources Management services and Centres of Expertise program.
The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of an internal realignment between Financial Management services and Centres of Expertise program.

The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of an increase in resources for an initiative approved in 2018-19 to migrate the infrastructure to the Cloud as well as additional spending related to internal information technology support.
The decrease in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of an internal realignment between Real Property Management services and Centres of Expertise program.

The decrease in Oversight and Treasury Board Support program full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to minor vacancies in the Economic sector, the Government Operations sector and the International Affairs, Security and Justice sector.

program_name: Expenditure Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews
variance_explanation: The increase in Expenditure Data, Analysis and Reviews program spending is mainly attributable to an increase in paylist expenditures: civilian severance pay and termination benefits; vacation credits payable upon termination of employment with the Public Service; parental benefits; and termination benefits for Ministers' exempt staff.

The variance is attributable to the way Government-Wide Funds are transferred between the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat (TBS) and other government organizations. Each year, TBS includes this funding in its reference levels to be transferred to government organizations once specific criteria are met. Unused central vote funding is lapsed.

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2022-23 to 2023-24 in Financial Management Policies and Initiatives is associated with additional funding announced in 2020–21 for Phoenix stabilization and HR-to-Pay initiatives (Budget 2021), notably for the Government-Wide Claims Office, which is scheduled to sunset in 2022-23 and is subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The increase in Financial Management Policies and Initiatives program spending is mainly attributable to additional funding received for executive compensation allocations. The increase in full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to increased support for Phoenix stabilization.

The increase in Digital Policy program spending and full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to additional funding to support the Governance and Oversight of Digital Initiatives. The increase in full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to growth within the Digital Policies and Services and Chief Data Officer divisions of the Office of the Chief Information Officer.

planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2022-23 to 2023-24 for Digital Strategy, Planning, and Oversight is mainly attributable to a reduction to the funding to Access to Information Review and Action Plan (Budget 2021), which is scheduled to sunset in 2023-24, and the funding for the Policy on COVID-19 Vaccination for the Core Public Administration including the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (off-cycle funding approved for two years starting 2021-22), which is scheduled to sunset in 2022-23.  Both initiatives are subject to the renewal process.

The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for Digital Strategy, Planning, and Oversight is mainly attributable to the funding to Access to Information Review and Action Plan (Budget 2021), which is scheduled to sunset in 2022-23 and subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The increase in Digital Strategy, Planning, and Oversight program spending and full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to additional funding received to support Governance and Oversight of Digital Initiatives.
The increase in Management Accountability Framework program spending is mainly attributable to additional funding received for executive compensation allocations.

program_name: Acquired Services and Assets Policies and Initiatives
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for Acquired Services and Assets Policies and Initiatives is mainly attributable to the funding for the Centre of Expertise for Real Property, which is sunsetting in 2023-24 and a reduction to the funding for the Government Contracts, Including Real Property Leases, in the Nunavut Settlement Area.  Both initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The increase in Acquired Services and Assets Policies and Initiatives program full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to an increase in the Investment Planning and Project Management division of the Office of the Comptroller General.
The increase in Digital Comptrollership program spending and full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to increased funding to support Financial Management Transformation.

The increase in Internal Audit Policies and Initiatives program spending and full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to additional funding received to support the Capacity Accelerator Project, which aims to reinforce the internal audit function's role in the Government of Canada.

program_name: Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives
variance_explanation: The increase in Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives program spending and full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to the increased workload required to meet departmental priorities.
The increase in Canadian Digital Services program full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to additional support for Canadian Digital Service program delivery.

planning_explanation: The increase of planned spending for Greening Government Operations from 2022-23 to 2024-25 is attributable to the funding to implement a federal Low Carbon Fuel Procurement Program and the renewal of the funding for the Greening Government Fund.
variance_explanation: The decrease in Greening Government Operations program spending is mainly attributable to an increase in funding transfers to various organizations to support projects which will reduce greenhouse gas emissions in federal government operations. The increase in full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to additional personnel to deliver the greening government program.

planning_explanation:
The decrease of planned spending from 2022-23 to 2023-24 for Public Service Accessibility is mainly due to the reprofiling of funds in the Centralized Enabling Workplace Fund from 2019-20 to 2022-23. 

The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for Public Service Accessibility is mainly attributable to the sunsetting of Funding to renew the Office of Public Service Accessibility (Budget 2021) and the Funding for the Centralized Enabling Workplace Fund.  Both initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The increase in Public Service Accessibility program full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to additional funding received during the fiscal year for the Centralized Enabling Workplace Fund.

planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2022-23 to 2023-24 for Employment Conditions and Labour Relations is mainly attributable to the funding to advance public service job classification (Budget 2021) starting in 2021-22 for two years, the funding for the Policy on COVID-19 Vaccination for the Core Public Administration including the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (off-cycle funding approved for two years starting 2021-22), and additional funding announced in 2020–21 for Phoenix stabilization and HR-to-Pay initiatives (Budget 2021).  All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.

The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for Employment Conditions and Labour Relations is mainly attributable to the funding announced in the Budget 2019 for the Pay Equity initiative sunsetting in 2024-25 and is subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The increase in Employee Relations and Total Compensation program spending is mainly attributable to additional funding received for out-of-court settlements. The increase in full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to two activities: the management of public service insurance and benefits; and employee relations and total compensation.

The decrease in Pension and Benefits Management program spending and full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to the subsummation of this program into the Employee Relations and Total Compensation program.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2022-23 to 2023-24 for Workplace Policies and Services is attributable to the funding announced in the 2020 Fall Economic Statement to Foster a diverse and inclusive public service initiative that is scheduled to sunset at the end of 2022-23 and is subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in Workplace Policies and Services program spending is mainly attributable to a reduction in Office of the Chief Human Resources Officer spending on Diversity and Inclusion and Official Languages. The increase in full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to the additional support required for Diversity and Inclusion initiatives.

planning_explanation: The increase of planned spending from 2022-23 to 2024-25 for Public Service Employer Payments is attributable to the approved additional funding for the Public Service Insurance Plans to ensure financial sustainability of the public service group insurance plans and programs.
variance_explanation: The increase in Public Service Employer Payments program spending is mainly attributable to an increase in spending on the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Life and Disability plans because of approved disability claims and related payments, further to the recent signing of the first collective agreement for regular members, which is a key determinant of the amount of a disability benefit payment.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2022-23 to 2023-24 for Executive and Leadership Development is attributable to the funding for the Joint Learning Program and to the funding announced in the 2020 Fall Economic Statement to Foster a diverse and inclusive public service initiative that are both scheduled to sunset at the end of 2022-23.  Both initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The increase in Executive and Leadership Development program spending is mainly attributable to an increase in spending on executive management and leadership development managed by the Office of Chief Human Resource Officer.

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2022-23 to 2023-24 in People Management Systems and Processes is mainly associated with additional funding announced in 2020–21 for Phoenix stabilization and HR-to-Pay initiatives (Budget 2021), which is scheduled to sunset in 2022-23 and is subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in People Management Systems and Processes program spending is mainly attributable to a reduction in spending on HR-to-Pay initiatives. The increase in full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to the additional support required for HR-to-Pay initiatives.

The increase in Research, Planning and Renewal program spending is mainly attributable to an increase in Office of the Chief Human Resources Officer spending on Workforce Business Intelligence Services. The increase in full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to the Office of the Chief Human Resources Officer delivery of Research and Experimentation and Workforce Business Intelligence Services.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2022-23 to 2023-24 for Regulatory Policy, Oversight, and Cooperation is mainly attributable to the Funding for regulatory reviews and the External Advisory Committee on Regulatory Competitiveness, which is scheduled to sunset in 2022-23 and is subject to the renewal process.

variance_explanation: The decrease in Management and Oversight Services program full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to budget reallocations to other programs and employee attrition.

The increase in Communications Services program spending and full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to increased funding to support Governance and Oversight of Digital Initiatives and funding for the development of a mental health fund for Black federal public servants.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending from 2022-23 to 2023-24 for Legal Services is mainly attributable to the sunsetting of corporate costs funding related to the Policy on COVID-19 Vaccination for the Core Public Administration including the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (off-cycle funding approved for two years starting 2021-22).

variance_explanation: The increase in Human Resources Management Services program spending and full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to increased funding to support for Governance and Oversight of Digital Initiatives and funding for compensation allocations.

The increase in Financial Management Services program full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to the additional full-time equivalents hired to onboard new departments to the Central Agencies Cluster-Shared Systems.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending from 2022-23 to 2024-25 for Information Management Services is mainly attributable to a reduction of funding for corporate costs as a result of various sunsetting initiatives.
variance_explanation: The decrease in Information Management Services program spending is mainly attributable to internal reallocations required to fund sector pressures.
The increase in Information Technology Services program spending is mainly attributable to an increase in enterprise resource planning initiatives.
The increase in Real Property Management Services program spending is mainly attributable to spending on security and the management of facilities and asset.
The decrease in Material Management Services program spending is mainly attributable to decreased spending on workplace renovations and facilities management.
The increase in Acquisition Management Services is mainly attributable to increased spending on corporate administration and security.

planning_explanation: Over the planning period 2022-23 to 2024-25, the Board’s planned spending and planned resources are relatively unchanged.
variance_explanation: Actual spending increased compared with planned spending as the Board received temporary funding to address increased demand for review and appeal services.

organization: Secretariat of the National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians
core_responsibility: Parliamentary Review of National Security and Intelligence Activities

organization: Secretariat of the National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians

planning_explanation:
Financials:
* Sunset (at the end of 2022-23) of program integrity funding for non-insured health benefits for First Nations and Inuit (Budget 2021)
* Increase in funding as an allocation of funding (starting in 2023-24) is no longer required to support the implementation of _British Columbia Tripartite Framework Agreement on First Nation Health Governance_ for the transfer to the First Nations Health Authority
* Net increase in other funding for the non-insured health benefits for First Nations and Inuit
variance_explanation:
SPENDING: The difference between 2022-23 Planned Spending and Actual Spending is primarily to ensure client access to non-insured health benefits for First Nations and Inuit, and additional funding was requested due to COVID-19 uncertainty. This resulted in a surplus.

FTEs: The variance in FTE utilization within First Nations and Inuit Health programs is to meet overall health needs for members of First Nations and Inuit communities and address health programs priorities and requirements.

planning_explanation:
Financials:
* Increase in funding as an allocation of funding (starting in 2023-24) is no longer required to support the implementation of the _British Columbia Tripartite Framework Agreement on First Nation Health Governance_ for the transfer to the First Nations Health Authority
* Increase in funding for a mercury care home and a water treatment facility for Asubpeeschoseewagong Netum Anishinabek, and a mercury wellness centre for Wabaseemoong Independent Nations
* Sunset (at the end of 2022-23) of funding to support medical transportation in Nunavut
* Net increase in other funding for the Clinical and Client Care program

FTEs:
The increase from 2022-23 through 2024-25 is due to new funding approved for this program.
variance_explanation:
SPENDING: The difference between 2022-23 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for supporting COVID-19 public health responses and the Indigenous Community Support Fund (Budget 2022).

FTEs: The variance in FTE utilization within First Nations and Inuit Health programs is to meet overall health needs for members of First Nations and Inuit communities and address health programs priorities and requirements.

FTEs:

SPENDING: The difference between 2022-23 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects a shift in priorities from planned activities to focus more on resumption of oral health services in communities, post COVID-19 pandemic. 

FTEs: The variance in FTE utilization within First Nations and Inuit Health programs is to meet overall health needs for members of First Nations and Inuit communities and address health programs priorities and requirements.

planning_explanation:
Financials:
Primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2022-23) of funding to address sex-based inequities in Indian status registration

FTEs:
From 2022-23 onwards the variance is due to the reduction related to Funding to address sex-based inequities in Indian status resolved by the removal of the 1951 cut-off.
variance_explanation:
SPENDING: The difference between 2022-23 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects: 

* an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
  - costs related to compensation to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle programs; and
  - improving _Indian Act_ registration services.
* an increase in allocation of funding:
  - from the New Fiscal Relationship grant due to lower than anticipated recipients number for the grant. The unused grant funding is returned to the programs to be made available to First Nations via other funding mechanisms; and
  - to meet departmental priorities.
* the deferral of funding to future years for costs related to compensation and for the reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle programs. These funds could not be spent in 2022-23 and are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

FTEs: Increase in FTEs reflects services provided in the Northern Regions.

program_name: Jordan's Principle and the Inuit Child First Initiative
planning_explanation:
Financials:
Primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2022-23) of funding for the continued implementation of Jordan’s Principle
* sunset (at the end of 2023-24) of funding to support Inuit Child First Initiative

FTEs:
Decrease in 2023-24 is due to the sunset of First Nation funding.
variance_explanation:
SPENDING: The difference between 2022-23 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the continued implementation of Jordan’s Principle and Inuit Child First Initiative. This is a demand-driven program thus the deferral of funding for Jordan’s Principle and Inuit Child First Initiative to future years for the intended purposes.

FTEs: The variance in FTE utilization is because of increased  workload due to demand driven nature of this initiative as well as due to incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the continued implementation of Jordan’s Principle.

planning_explanation:
Financials:
* Sunset (at the end of 2023-24) of funding for mental health and wellness (Budget 2021)
* Sunset (at the end of 2023-24) of funding for Indigenous distinctions-based mental wellness (Budget 2021)
* Net increase in other funding for the Mental Wellness program
* Increase in funding as an allocation of funding (starting in 2023-24) is no longer required to support the implementation of  the British Columbia Tripartite Framework Agreement on First Nation Health Governance for the transfer to the First Nations Health Authority

FTEs:
Decrease in 2024-25 is due to the sunset of Indian Residential Schools, Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, and Indian Day School programs.
variance_explanation:
SPENDING: The difference between 2022-23 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:

* an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
  - implementing the federal framework to address the legacy of residential schools (Budget 2022); 
  - supporting Indigenous participation in the papal visit to Canada; and
  - costs related to compensation to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle programs. 

* the deferral of funding to future years for:
  - costs related to compensation and for the reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle programs;
  - Indigenous distinctions-based mental wellness and trauma-informed health and cultural supports; and 
  - implementing the federal framework to address the legacy of residential schools (Budget 2022). 
   These funds could not be spent in 2022-23 and are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would   be available for the intended purposes.

program_name: First Nations Child and Family Services
planning_explanation:
Financials:
Primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2022-23) of funding for out-of-court settlements
* a net increase in funding for Child and Family Services

FTEs:
The increase in FTEs from 2022-23 to 2023-24 is due to the funding approved to implement the C-92 Act and the decrease in FTEs from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is due to the sunset of Compensation funding.
variance_explanation:
SPENDING: The difference between 2022-23 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
* an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
  - costs related to compensation and for the reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle programs;
  - advancing the implementation and operationalization of Indigenous children and family servicesʼ laws; and
  - First Nations Child and Family Services, Canadian Human Rights Tribunal orders implementation and non-compliance motion settlement (Budget 2021).

* lapse at year-end that will return to the fiscal framework for:
  - the reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle programs; and
  - advancing the implementation and operationalization of Indigenous children and family servicesʼ laws.

* the deferral of funding to future years for:
  - an out-of-court settlement; and
  - costs related to compensation and for the reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle programs.
   These funds could not be spent in 2022-23 and are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

FTEs: The difference between Planned and Actual FTEs is mainly due to the additional FTEs received from additional funding for First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle and for additional resources for C-92 implementation.

planning_explanation:
Financials:
Primarily reflect:
* an increase in funding for the construction and operation of shelters and transition houses for Indigenous women, children and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people
variance_explanation:
SPENDING: The difference between 2022-23 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
* an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
  - the Family Violence Prevention Program;
  - the construction and operation of shelters and transition houses for Indigenous women, children and 2SLGBTQI+ people; and
  - the Pathways to Safe Indigenous Communities Initiative (Budget 2021).

* the deferral of funding to future years for the construction and operation of shelters and transition houses for Indigenous women, children and 2SLGBTQI+ people. These funds could not be spent in 2022-23 and are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

planning_explanation: The Canadian Pari-Mutuel Agency's vote-netted revenue, operating costs and Employee Benefit Plan are being adjusted to reflect the forecasts in their 2023-24 to 2025-26 Business Plan. The revenues are generated through the regulation and supervision of pari-mutuel betting on horse racing at racetracks across Canada.
variance_explanation: The Canadian Pari-Mutuel Agency is not funded through an appropriation of public funds but rather through a levy on all money bet in Canada on horse racing. Therefore, the revenue and actual spending each year will vary.

variance_explanation: As part of the Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (Sustainable CAP) five-year Framework, Federal-Provincial-Territorial Cost-shared programming is designed and delivered by the provinces and territories. In 2023-24, there was no planned spending as the new funding for Sustainable CAP was not included in last year’s Main Estimates due to timing of its approval; however, it was subsequently included in Supplementary Estimates in 2023-24.

AgriStability is demand-driven, rather than being funded from a set allocation for each fiscal year. Although the administrative costs of the program remain relatively constant, the variance of year-to-year grant and contribution payments is directly related to participation and industry conditions.  In 2023-24, actual spending was greater than planned spending mostly due to the new funding for the Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (Sustainable CAP) that was not included in last year’s Main Estimates due to timing of its approval; however, it was subsequently included in Supplementary Estimates in 2023-24. Furthermore, higher spending was also driven by an unexpected price decline for major crop commodities and hogs.

AgriInvest is demand-driven and the variance from year-to-year in grant and contribution expenditures is directly related to both participation and commodity prices. Producer deposits and government contributions are based on a percentage of income generated from the sale of commodities for a production period (Allowable Net Sales).  In 2023-24, actual spending was greater than planned spending mostly due to the new funding for the Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (Sustainable CAP) that was not included in last year’s Main Estimates due to timing of its approval; however, it was subsequently included in Supplementary Estimates in 2023-24. Furthermore, actual spending was greater due to higher grain, oilseed and livestock prices which led to higher Allowable Net Sales resulting in higher payments.

In 2023-24, actual full-time equivalents were more than planned due to a realignment among programs to better manage operational work load, taking into account the increased operational tempo driven by the emerging priorities, including the Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership.

planning_explanation: Please note that the funding authorities for the new five-year Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (Sustainable CAP) were not yet approved at the time of publishing this Departmental Plan, and are thus not reflected in the 2023-24 and future years spending amounts provided throughout this report. Funding for the Sustainable CAP will be reflected in the 2023–24 Supplementary Estimates, as well as in the 2024–25 Departmental Plan and 2023–24 Departmental Results Report.
variance_explanation: AgriRecovery is demand-driven. Spending under the framework varies from year-to-year depending on the need for disaster response initiatives. . In 2023-24, there was no planned spending as the new funding for the Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (Sustainable CAP) was not included in last year’s Main Estimates due to timing of its approval; however, it was subsequently included in Supplementary Estimates in 2023-24. Furthermore, actual spending was greater due to increased funding provided in 2023-24 to support drought and grasshopper infestations in British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan as well as wildfires in British Columbia.

In 2023-24, actual spending was greater than planned spending mostly due to the new funding for the Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (Sustainable CAP) that was not included in last year’s Main Estimates due to timing of its approval; however, it was subsequently included in Supplementary Estimates in 2023-24. Furthermore, actual spending was greater due to the increase of premium rates resulting from the 2021 drought and because of commodity prices mainly, related to canola and wheat.

The Advance Payments Program under the Agricultural Marketing Programs Act is demand-driven and the variance from year-to-year in statutory contribution expenditures is directly related to interest rates, participation, weather and commodity prices. In 2023-24, actual spending was greater than planned spending due to new federal funding received for the Advance Payments Program to support changes to the regulations to increase the interest-free loan limit of the program for all producers and consequently producers taking larger advances.  In addition, interest rates were higher than the same period last year and there was higher participation in the program.
Farm Debt Mediation Services is a demand-driven program based on participants' individual financial situations and whether or not they seek mediation services.

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending from 23-24 to 25-26 is mainly attributable to the ramping down of the current phase in the Canadarm 3 project as well as the end of additional funding for the participation in the International Space Station (ISS).
variance_explanation:
Spending: The variance is mainly due to delays caused by the increased complexity of the Lunar Gateway's requirements and current economic challenges, leading to supply chain delays and the non-completion of certain key milestones in the Canadarm3 and Gateway External Robotic Interfaces (GERI) projects.

FTE: The variance is mainly due to internal reallocation to support space exploration sector such as Canadarm3 as well as an increase in the supply of student internships during the year.

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending from 23-24 to 25-26 is due to the end of the preparation phase of the Earth Observation Service Continuity (EOSC) initiative and the ramping down of the demonstration portion of the WildFireSat mission (WFS).
variance_explanation: Spending: The variance is mainly due to the WildFireSat project due to delays in obtaining project and contract authority approvals during the definition phase.

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to the reduction of the project initiative inside the European Space Agency (ESA) Program.

variance_explanation: The variance is mainly due to additional resources to support STEM, Artemis II, and the Canadarm3 mission.

The variance is mainly due to the increase in human resources capacity to increase hiring capacity.

variance_explanation: The variance between the planned and actual spending is primarily due to additional integrity funding, collective agreement funding and one-time Information Technology (IT) funding for IT investments, that had not yet been confirmed at the time the Departmental Plan was prepared. This additional funding was confirmed during the fiscal year and is included in the actual spending figures.

core_responsibility: Independent regulatory and dispute-resolution services for transportation providers and users
variance_explanation: The 2023-24 planned resources were set out in the 2023-24 Departmental Plan. However, since the tabling of the 2023-24 Departmental Plan, the Agency received approval for $20.6 million in temporary funding via Budget 2023. This renewal and increase in temporary funding allowed the Agency to increase its staff complement in order to continue to respond to a higher number of air passenger and accessibility related complaints as well as continue its comprehensive review of business processes in order to better serve Canadians. The 2023-24 actual resources are a reflection of this increase in funding.

core_responsibility: Independent regulatory and dispute-resolution services for transportation providers and users
variance_explanation: The 2023-24 planned resources were set out in the 2023-24 Departmental Plan. However, since the tabling of the 2023-24 Departmental Plan, the Agency received approval for $20.6 million in temporary funding via Budget 2023. This renewal and increase in temporary funding allowed the Agency to increase its staff complement in order to expand its compliance and verification activities as well as modernize its enforcement tools. The 2023-24 actual resources are a reflection of this increase in funding.

The 2023-24 planned resources stem from the 2023-24 Departmental Plan. However, since the tabling of the 2023-24 Departmental Plan, the Agency received approval for $20.6 million in temporary funding via Budget 2023. This renewal and increase in temporary funding allowed the Agency to make investments in technology to improve its systems as well as better support the Agency's increased efforts in providing dispute resolution services to Canadians. The 2023-24 actual resources are a reflection of this increase in funding.

program_name: Copyright Tariff Setting and Issuance of Licences

planning_explanation: The change from 2023 to 2024 is due to a decrease in the funding received for class action court settlements.
variance_explanation: Expenditures in Institutional Management and Support were lower than anticipated due to delays which were beyond CSC’s control in the processing of claims related to class actions.

Expenditures in Clinical Services and Public Health increased relative to funding received during the year to cover expenditures due to changes in offender population and price fluctuations as well as funding received due to the ratification of collective agreements.

planning_explanation: An increase in the funding received for Transforming Federal Corrections (Bill C-83).

variance_explanation: Expenditures in Food Services increased relative to funding received during the year to cover expenditures due to changes in offender population and price fluctuations as well as funding received due to the ratification of collective agreements.

Expenditures in Accommodation Services increased relative to funding received during the year for supplementary estimates B (enhanced cleaning protocols, modernizing existing security equipment, reduction of suspension points, and reprofiled capital funding from the prior year), supplementary estimates C (maintain and repair correctional facilities and funding received to cover expenditures due to changes in offender population and price fluctuations), collective agreements, and the capital budget carry-forward.
Expenditures in Preventive Security and Intelligence increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements.
Expenditures in Offender Case Management increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements.
Expenditures in Community Engagement increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements.
Funds available for planned spending in Elder Services were not sufficient to cover 2023 to 2024 expenditures in Aboriginal Initiatives – Elder Services and Spiritual Advisor Services.

Expenditures in CORCAN Employment and Employability increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements. Funds available for planned spending were not sufficient to cover the 2023 to 2024 expenditures to meet various operational requirements.
Expenditures in Social Program increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements.
Expenditures in Correctional Programs increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements.

planning_explanation: The Community-Based Residential Facilities (CBRF) Program contributes to Community Supervision by providing accommodation to offenders in CBRFs operated by non-governmental agencies under contract with CSC.
variance_explanation: Expenditures in Community-Based Residential Facilities increased relative to funding received during the year to cover expenditures due to changes in offender population and price fluctuations.
Expenditures in Community Correctional Centres increased relative to funding received during the year to cover expenditures due to changes in offender population and price fluctuations.

Expenditures in Management and Oversight Services increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements and supplementary estimates B (offender redress and essential network enhancements).
Expenditures in Communications Services increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements.

Expenditures in Human Resources Management Services increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements and the operating budget carry-forward. Funds available for planned spending were not sufficient to cover the 2023 to 2024 expenditures to meet various operational requirements.

Expenditures in Information Management Services increased relative to funding received during the year due to the ratification of collective agreements. Funds available for planned spending were not sufficient to cover the 2023 to 2024 expenditures, mainly due to a realignment of capital projects.

Expenditures in Information Technology Services increased relative to funding received during the year for supplementary estimates B (equipment and licenses to maintain a hybrid workforce and essential network enhancements), due to the ratification of collective agreements, and for the operating and capital budget carry-forward. Funds available for planned spending were not sufficient to cover the 2023 to 2024 expenditures and there was a significant increase in spending from the previous year.
Expenditures in Real Property Management Services decreased, mostly in leasehold improvements that did not materialize.
New staffing in Acquisition Management Services was implemented following funding received during the year. Employees were transferred to this program to meet operational demands.

* Extend overseas intake under CUAET (Canada-Ukraine Authorization for Emergency Travel) until July 15, 2023 and extend facilitation at the port-of-entry as well as in-Canada processing until March 31, 2024;
* Address negotiated salary increases arising from newly signed collective agreements and other compensation-related adjustments for agreements; 
* Carry forward eligible lapsing operating funds from 2022-23 to 2023-24; as well as
* An internal reallocation of funds from other programs to address the increase in biometrics costs.

The variance is also attributable to an Employee Benefits Plan adjustment following the ratification of collective agreements.

core_responsibility: Immigrant and Refugee Selection and Integration
planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned spending from 2023-24 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to:
•	The phase down of resettlement and settlement services and processing activities as the Government of Canada’s commitment to resettle at least 40,000 Afghan nationals by the end of 2023 is being fulfilled; and
•	The phase down of funding related to the immigration approach to ensure Ukrainian nationals receive one-time temporary financial support until the end of June 2023.

The decrease in the planned FTEs from 2023-24 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to:
•	The phase down of resettlement and settlement services and processing activities as the Government of Canada’s commitment to resettle at least 40,000 Afghan nationals by the end of 2023 is being fulfilled; and
•	The phase down of processing activities as we deliver on the targets for the 2022-24 Immigration Levels Plan.
variance_explanation:
**($)**
The variance is mainly attributable to new in-year funding received by the department to:
* Implement the 2023 to 2025 Immigration Levels Plan; 
* Extend overseas intake under CUAET (Canada-Ukraine Authorization for Emergency Travel) until July 15, 2023;
* Cover incremental costs related to the provision of health-care benefits to eligible beneficiaries under the Interim Federal Health Program (IFHP); and
* Continue to provide income support to Afghan Refugees under the Resettlement Assistance Program (RAP).

As the department achieved its targets to resettle 40,000 Afghan nationals to Canada, a surplus was identified as a result of lower than anticipated costs during the planning stage. The variance is also attributable to a surplus under the Resettlement Assistance Program due to delays in the execution of planned activities and labour shortages.

**FTE**
The variance is mainly attributable to new in-year funding received by the department to implement the 2023 to 2025 Immigration Levels Plan.

The variance is also attributable to a transfer to Global Affairs Canada (GAC) to support the ongoing Afghanistan Task Force; along with a realignment of resources to other programs to meet operational requirements. Furthermore, as the department achieved its targets to resettle 40,000 Afghan nationals to Canada, a surplus was identified as a result of lower than anticipated resources during the planning stage.

core_responsibility: Immigrant and Refugee Selection and Integration
planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned spending from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is mainly attributable to the decrease of available funding for temporary accommodations and support services provided to asylum seekers.

The decrease in the planned FTEs from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable temporary top-up to allow for a higher number of asylum claim finalizations ending in 2023-24 and the stabilization of permanent capacity to process 50,000 asylum claims per year.
variance_explanation:
**($)**
The variance is mainly attributable to new in-year funding received by the department to:
* Compensate provinces and municipalities for the interim housing of asylum claimants in 2023-24 under the Interim Housing Assistance Program (IHAP); 
* Cover incremental costs related to the provision of health-care benefits to eligible beneficiaries under the Interim Federal Health Program (IFHP); and
* Continue providing temporary accommodations and support services to asylum claimants.

A portion of the funds received under the IHAP will be carried over to 2024-25 to ensure that provinces and municipalities are provided reimbursement for costs incurred in the housing of asylum claimants for the first quarter of 2024. Furthermore, the variance is also attributable to a surplus under the IFHP as result of contingency funds not being required in full.

**FTE**
The variance is also attributable to lower than anticipated resources during the planning stage, along with a realignment of resources to other programs to meet operational requirements.

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is mainly attributable to an anticipated increase in the Passport Program’s revenues associated to the renewal of applications for the 10 year passport combined with a reduction in temporary costs associated to the operational impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. The net increase in the planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is as a result of a slightly lower forecasted demand in the passport applications between these two fiscal years.
variance_explanation:
**($)**
The results for the year 2023-24 showed a smaller rise in travel document requests than initially anticipated during the planning phase, resulting in lower revenues than expected. Additionally, program delivery costs exceeded the original projections. This cost increase stemmed from various factors, including inflation, higher operational expenses incurred in managing and clearing processing backlogs, increased costs related to passport materials and freight, as well as elevated expenses associated with the implementation and execution of modernization projects.

The decrease in the planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to legal services provided by the Department of Justice, in particular for the anticipated increase in litigation relating to asylum decisions and litigation support services for those proceedings.

planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned spending is mainly due to the expiry of budgetary spending authorities in 2024-25 to develop a national strategy for high-cost drugs for rare diseases. The department would have to request funding for this initiative for future years. 

The decrease in planned FTEs is mainly due to the expiry of budgetary spending authorities in 2023-24 for the Canadian Drug Agency Transition Office, as well as in 2024-25 to develop a national strategy for high-cost drugs for rare diseases. The department would have to request funding for these initiatives for future years.
variance_explanation:
The variance between actual and planned spending is mainly due to additional in-year funding for Working together to improve health care for Canadians. This is partially offset by the frozen allotment for Drugs for Rare Diseases.

The variance in FTE utilization is mainly due to a realignment of resources based on operational requirements.

The department would have to request funding for this initiative for future years.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending is mainly explained by the sunsetting of the Supporting Black Canadian Communities Initiative funding in the fiscal year 2023 to 2024 and by a reprofile ending in the fiscal year 2023 to 2024 for the Community Services Recovery Fund.
variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending is primarily due the reallocation of funding from various program areas within the Department to meet the needs of the Supporting Black Canadian Communities Initiative. In addition, in-year funding was received from Budget 2023 to support the capacity building for non-profit disability organizations. 

The variance between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) reflects the realignment of additional resources required due to additional funding received for the Social Development Partnerships Program.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
program_name: Canadian Benefit for Parents of Young Victims of Crime
variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending is due to fewer applications being received than forecasted at the grant's initiation in 2013. Changes to the program were made in Spring 2023 to enhance the grant by expanding eligibility criteria, increasing flexibility, and enhancing financial support for eligible working parents by raising the grant amount to $500 from $450. It is expected that, over time, these changes will have a modest but important impact on uptake of the grant.

No significant variance for full-time equivalents (FTEs).

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
program_name: Indigenous Early Learning and Child Care Transformation Initiative
planning_explanation: The planned spending increase is mainly due to a reduction in funding transfers to other government departments by the fiscal year 2025 to 2026 and to an increase in the funding profile.
variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending is due to transfers of funding, after approval of the Departmental Plan, to other federal departments involved in the delivery of the Indigenous Early Learning and Child Care horizontal initiative. These transfers were made to reflect Indigenous leadership decisions on funding allocations and agreements.

No significant variance for full-time equivalents (FTEs).

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending is, for the most part,  explained by the actual funding profile of the Social Finance Fund, which front-loaded investments of $110 million in the fiscal year 2023 to 2024 and reduced the funding to $60 million per year, in the fiscal years 2024 to 2025 and 2025 to 2026.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending for the Strategic Engagement and Research Program is due to the Program only having permanent funding available for international grants to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), in the amount of $0.1 million per year, as it absorbed the former OECD Named Grant upon its creation. As a result, the Strategic Engagement and Research Program largely relies on the reallocation of existing resources within the Department each fiscal year in order to be able to carry out its mandate, which causes actuals to exceed planned spending. Total authorities were fully spent. 

No variance for full-time equivalents (FTEs).

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation:
The increase in planned spending is mainly attributable to an increase to Old Age Security pension and to Guaranteed Income Supplement statutory payments, mainly explained by an expected increased number of beneficiaries due to the aging population and expected increases to average monthly benefits, particularly resulting from the indexation of benefits using a higher forecasted inflation rate and the 10% increase in the Old Age Security pension for seniors aged 75 and older, in effect since July 2022.

The decrease in full-time equivalents is mainly the result of the sunsetting of temporary resources provided to address Old Age Security workload capacity and Benefits Delivery Modernization (Old Age Security Implementation).
variance_explanation: No significant variance

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending is due to lower than expected impact of Budget 2022 changes to the Income Tax Act permitted persons with type one diabetes (T1D) to be eligible for the Disability Tax Credit. Also, a reduction of average annual contributions from beneficiaries led to lower grant payments and a larger proportion of new Registered disability savings plan (RDSP) being opened by beneficiaries with higher income, and therefore ineligible for bond and lower grant amounts.

The variance between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) is mainly due to in-year additional resources to support the Canada Disability Savings Program.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation: The increase in gross planned spending is mainly explained by an increase to Canada Pension Plan (CPP) benefits due to an expected increase in the number of beneficiaries attributable to an aging population, and paying the CPP enhancement benefits, including retroactive payments from the year 2019.
variance_explanation:
No significant variance in gross spending. At net the variance between planned and actual spending is mainly due to employee benefit plans (EBP) expenses connected to additional staff hired to support ongoing work related to processing Canada Pension Plan workload to support demographically driven increases in workload inventories pressures.

The variances between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) is mainly due to additional staff hired to support ongoing work related to processing Canada Pension Plan workload to support demographically driven increases in workload inventories pressures.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation: The decrease in net planned spending and in full-time equivalents is mainly the result of the sunsetting of temporary resources provided to address the Employment Insurance processing and call centre workload.
variance_explanation:
No significant variance in gross spending. At net the variance between planned and actual spending is mainly due to the $286 million credited to the account for EI Emergency Response Benefit (EI-ERB) in fiscal year 2023 to 2024.

The variance between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) is mainly due to the hiring of additional resources to maintain timely service to Canadians.

The variance between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) is due to competing priorities that required the program to use fewer resources.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development

variance_explanation:
No significant variance between planned and actual spending.

The variance between planned and actual full-time equivalents (FTEs) is explained by the limited pool of qualified candidates in a tight labour market, the realignment of internal human resources to address emerging priorities and the expiration of Budget 2021 funding at the end of fiscal year 2023-24.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development

variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly due to additional authorities accessed by the department in-year, from Budget 2022 and Budget 2023, and compensation adjustments for new collective agreements.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development

program_name: Enabling Fund for Official Language Minority Communities
variance_explanation: The variances between planned and actual spending, as well as the full-time equivalents (FTEs) are due to the additional authorities accessed by the department in year, as a result of Budget 2023 commitment to Official Language Minority Communities, which was not included in the Departmental Plan.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
program_name: Canada Student Financial Assistance Program and Canada Apprentice Loan
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending is due to the expiration of the doubling of Canada Student Grants. This measure was announced in Budget 2021 and is set to expire at the end of July, 2023. The end of this measure will result in a decrease in program expenditures moving forward. This measure affects the Canada Student Grants and Canada Student Loans issued to students, as well as the alternative payments made to non-participating provinces and territories.
variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending is due to the measure announced in Budget 2023 increasing the maximum Canada Student Grants amount by 40 percent above pre-pandemic levels. This measure was not accounted for in the Main Estimates (planned spending) but was added through Supplementary Estimates following the announcement. Also, the actual spending includes the write-offs for which the Program obtained a proper voted authority.

No significant variance for full-time equivalents (FTEs).

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation: The increase in planned spending is due to higher Canada Education Savings Grant and Canada Learning Bond payments, as families' investments in Registered Education Savings Plans and the number of Canada Learning Bond recipients are expected to return to pre-pandemic levels in the year 2024.
variance_explanation: No significant variance

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents is explained by the end of Budget 2019 funding for the Outbound Student Mobility Pilot under the International Education Strategy and the end of the Goal Getters program funding from the Youth Employment and Skills Strategy.
variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending is largely due to new authorities accessed by the department in-year, from Fall Economic Statement 2022,  for the Supports for Student Learning program (SSLP), with $9.5 million for Pathways to Education Canada, $8 million for Indspire, and $9.5 million for SSLP not included in the planned spending. Also, additional funding was allocated internally to Indspire in the amount of $6.0 million.

No significant variance for full-time equivalents (FTEs).

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents is due to the reduction in temporary resources for the administration and the integrity of the Canada Emergency Response Benefit and the Employment Insurance  Emergency Response Benefit.
variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual spending as well as Full-time equivalents (FTE) is mainly attributable to the winding-down of the emergency benefits program after the emergency period, resulting in benefits expenditures lower than originally estimated; and to adjustments related to ongoing activities such as integrity and collection activities.

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending is due to the reduction in administration costs related to the Canada Recovery Benefit, the Canada Recovery Caregiving Benefit and the Canada Recovery Sickness Benefit.
variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending is due to planned spending determined on the best estimates at the time of the department plan elaboration. It is also explained by collection activities and integrity work performed on Canada Recovery Benefit (CRB) payments, resulting in repayments, cancellations or realignment between the Canada Recovery Benefit programs.

No significant variance for full-time equivalents (FTEs).

organization: Department of Employment and Social Development
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents after the fiscal year 2023 to 2024 is attributable to the sunsetting of the Budget 2021 funding provided to invest in skills, training and trades under the Community Workforce Development Program.
variance_explanation:
The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly due to delays in new projects, starting later than anticipated, leaving excess funding available. The department is aiming to reprofile unspent authority to future years.

variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual FTEs is mainly explained by an increase in demand from client departments for litigation services (such as: tax, class proceedings, immigration work and work on Indigenous files). The remainder of the variance is explained by the realignment of FTEs between programs to better reflect Departmental priorities.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by spending for the Independent Special Interlocutor for Missing Children and Unmarked Graves and Burial Sites associated with Indian Residential Schools, which is not included in the planned spending. The remainder of the variance is explained by additional items that were not included in planned spending including paylist expenditures (such as parental benefits), salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements and increases in personnel expenditures to support the increased workload for various initiatives.

planning_explanation:
2024-25:
The variance is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding as of March 31, 2024 (1) for the Criminal Legal Aid program, announced in Budget 2022 and (2) to Provide Legal Support and Awareness to Address Sexual Harassment in the Workplace.
variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by increased contribution spending resulting from additional funding received during the year to maintain federal support for immigration and refugee legal aid services, as announced in Budget 2023 and the Fall Economic Statement 2023.

The variance between planned and actual spending is explained by the fact that some provinces and territories are not yet ready to implement the Contraventions Act Regime and therefore did not incur expenditures as anticipated. The negotiations and progress depend largely on the priorities, and therefore capacity, of the provinces and territories. The funds will be completely committed once all jurisdictions have signed agreements. Some of the unused funds were reallocated internally to address funding pressures under other contributions programs.

The variance between planned and actual FTEs is mainly explained by employees on deployment or assignment when the planned FTE amount was established and who returned for the full year in 2023-24.
The variance between planned and actual FTEs is explained by the departure of an employee whose position is still vacant.

The variance between planned and actual spending is explained by increased contribution spending to respond to the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls’ Final Report: Increasing Access to Culturally Grounded and Indigenous-Led Victim Services, as announced in Budget 2023. The Department received additional funding during the year to support continued and expanded services through Family Information Liaison Units and Community Support and Healing for families of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, 2SLGBTQI+ people, men and boys and to support access to Indigenous-led victims services and supports. The increase was partially offset by a reduction in spending due to lower uptake by provinces and territories of funding to help ensure access to free legal advice and legal representation for victims of sexual assault (funding to advance the National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence, as announced in Budget 2021).
The variance between planned and actual FTEs is explained by the departure of an employee whose position is still vacant.

planning_explanation:
2024-25:
The variance is mainly explained by the sunset of  temporary grants and contributions funding received over the three-year period, from 2021-22 to 2023-24, (1) to Improve Access to Justice for Indigenous People and to address systemic barriers in the criminal justice system, and (2) to improve access to justice through Indigenous engagement on justice-related issues and the Reconciliation Secretariat. Additionally, there is a year-over-year decrease in funding for Gladue Principles - Systemic and Community-led Responses to Address Overrepresentation of Indigenous People in the Criminal Justice System.

2025-26:
The variance in mainly explained by year-over-year decreases in grants and contributions funding for (1) Gladue Principles - Systemic and Community-led Responses to Address Overrepresentation of Indigenous People in the Criminal Justice System, and (2) the Implementation of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act.
variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual FTEs is explained by departures whose positions were not immediately staffed as well as delays in planned staffing.

planning_explanation:
2024-25:
The variance is explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding received over the five-year period, from 2019-20 to 2023-24, (1) to support Renewed Legal Relationships with Indigenous Peoples by supporting Indigenous law initiatives across Canada (Call to Action 50), and (2) to Provide Legal Support and Awareness to Address Sexual Harassment in the Workplace.

2025-26:
The variance is mainly explained by the sunset of  temporary contributions funding received over the five-year period from 2020-21 to 2024-25 to increase access to family justice services in the official language of one’s choice.
variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual FTEs is explained by the departure of an employee whose position was not immediately staffed.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by increases in personnel expenditures to support the increased workload in order to deliver on the Ombudsperson for Victims of Crime mandate and provide services to Canadians. The remainder of the variance is mainly explained by salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements.

The variance between planned and actual FTEs is explained by an increase in staff needed to deliver on the Ombudsperson for Victims of Crime mandate and provide services to Canadians.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by the internal reallocation of resources according to the Department’s priorities. The remainder of the variance is explained by personnel expenditure increases due to salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by additional spending related to increased demand for services and advice, and salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements.

planning_explanation: All legal services resources and expenditures for the Department of Justice Canada are reported under its Legal Services Core Responsibility.
variance_explanation: All legal services resources and expenditures for the Department of Justice Canada are reported under its Legal Services Core Responsibility.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by the internal reallocation of resources according to the Department’s priorities. The remainder of the variance is mainly explained by increases in personnel expenditures to expand the Justice Language Training Program, for the launch of the Centre for Workplace Access-Ability, Health, and Wellness and for salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements and paylist expenditures (such as parental benefits) that were not included in planned spending.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by the internal reallocation of resources according to the Department’s priorities and expenditure increases related to in-year funding of information technology projects and internal pressures, which are excluded from planned spending (such as: investments to enhance connectivity, cloud services, security and software services, information technology equipment replenishment, and hybrid workspace related equipment and support).

The variance between planned and actual spending is explained by an increase in personnel expenditures for new employees needed to support higher demand for personnel security screening requests and for supporting the modernization of the security operations for Justice offices.

The variance between planned and actual FTEs is explained an increase in staff needed to meet the increase in demand and complexity of personnel security screening requests, and for supporting the modernization of the security operations for Justice offices.

The variance between planned and actual spending is explained by a reduction in personnel expenditures due to vacant positions that are yet to be filled.

The variance between planned and actual FTEs is explained by the departures of employees whose positions are still vacant.

The increase in FTEs is due to better alignment of the programming against the PI which led to the transfer of some FTEs from Natural Resources Canada’s Indigenous Partnerships Office – West PI. Also, additional resources were required to support National Benefits-Sharing Framework, Indigenous Economic Development and other programs that received in-year funding.
