The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements and growth in the workforce driven by an increase in demand from client departments for litigation services in areas such as class proceedings, support for responses to immigration and refugee issues, Indigenous-related matters and combatting tax evasion and avoidance.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements. In addition, spending increased resulting from funding to support government-wide Legislative and Regulatory Initiatives, as announced in the Fall Economic Statement 2022.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by salary expenditure increases. This increase was caused by retroactive payments and salary increments from ratified collective agreements, the growth in the workforce to meet the increased demand for legal services from several client departments, and the staffing realignment between programs to better reflect Departmental priorities.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by increased contribution spending for the implementation of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act, as announced in Budget 2022; and for the development and early implementation of the Indigenous Justice Strategy, as announced in Budget 2024 and the Canada Black Justice Strategy. The remainder of the variance is explained by salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements, and increases in spending for initiatives such as the Independent Special Interlocutor for Missing Children and Unmarked Graves and Burial Sites associated with Indian Residential Schools.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by increased contribution spending for Immigration and Refugee Legal Aid and Criminal Legal Aid. These increases resulted from additional funding received during the year to maintain federal support for immigration and refugee legal aid services, as announced in Budget 2024, and to maintain federal support for the delivery of criminal legal aid services in the provinces, as announced in Budget 2024.

The variance between planned and actual spending is explained by the fact that some provinces and territories were not yet ready to implement the Contraventions Act Regime and therefore did not incur expenditures as anticipated. The negotiations and progress depend largely on the priorities, and therefore capacity, of the provinces and territories. The funds will be completely committed once all jurisdictions have signed agreements. Some of the unused funds were reallocated internally to address funding pressures under the Immigration and Refugee Legal Aid Program.

planning_explanation: The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding for Enhancing the Federal Response to Address Gender-Based Violence and Advancing the National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence.

The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding received over the five-year period from 2020-21 to 2024-25 to increase access to family justice services in the official language of one’s choice.

The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding for Enhancing the Federal Response to Address Gender-Based Violence and Advancing the National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence.

The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 planned spending is mainly explained by year-over-year decreases in grants and contributions funding for (1) Gladue Principles - Systemic and Community-led Responses to Address Overrepresentation of Indigenous People in the Criminal Justice System, and (2) the Implementation of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act.

The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding received over the five-year period from 2020-21 to 2024-25 to increase access to family justice services in the official language of one’s choice.

The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding for (1) Enhancing the Federal Response to Address Gender-Based Violence and Advancing the National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence, (2) Funding to Provide Legal Services and Supports for Racialized Communities, and (3) Funding to Support Community Justice Centres.

variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by increases in salary expenditures due to growth in the workforce to support the increased workload in order to deliver on the Ombudsperson for Victims of Crime mandate and provide services to Canadians, and for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by increases in salary expenditures due to growth in the workforce to support the increased workload for various evolving governmental and departmental pressures, priorities and initiatives, and for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements. In addition, there is an increase in spending for supporting government-wide Legislative and Regulatory Initiatives, as announced in Fall Economic Statement 2022 and for the Public Inquiry into Foreign Interference in Federal Electoral Processes and Democratic Institutions, as announced in Budget 2024.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by the salary expenditure increases due to increases in the workforce, and for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements. In addition, there is increased expenditures related to funding received in-year for the implementation of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act, as announced in Budget 2022; and the development and early implementation of the Indigenous Justice Strategy, as announced in Budget 2024.

planning_explanation: All legal services resources and expenditures for the Department of Justice Canada are reported under its Legal Services Core Responsibility.
variance_explanation: All legal services resources and expenditures for the Department of Justice Canada are reported under its Legal Services Core Responsibility.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by increases in salary expenditures due to growth in the workforce to support an increased workload. This workload increase was mainly needed for the Centre for Workplace Access-Ability, Health, and Wellness, the expansion of Legal Excellence Program, and for responding to the audit on pay timeliness. In addition, salary expenditures increased for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by salary expenditure increases due to growth in the workforce, retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by salary expenditure increases due to growth in the workforce, retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements, and expenditure increases related to in-year funding of information management projects and internal pressures, such as departmental connectivity services and the delivery of artificial intelligence.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by salary expenditure increases due to growth in the workforce and expenditure increases related to in-year funding of information technology projects and internal pressures, such as the human resources system, investments to enhance security and software services, information and privacy modernization, cloud connectivity services, Robotic Process Automation and departmental connectivity services.

The variance between planned and actual spending is explained by an increase in salary expenditures due to growth in the workforce to support the modernization of the security operations for Justice offices, the expansion and related staffing increases in the regional offices, and the expansion in business management and governance.

The variance between planned and actual spending is mainly explained by salary expenditure increases for retroactive payments and salary increments related to the ratification of collective agreements.

However, the decrease in spending was partially offset by additional spending on activities related to the Electricity Pre-development Program.

planning_explanation: The variance is primarily due to reduction in expected royalty for the Newfoundland Offshore Petroleum Resource Revenue Fund. Royalty amounts vary year-to-year as a result of fluctuations in crude oil prices, exchange rates, changes in production levels, the timing of sales and Corporate Income Tax (CIT) collected.
variance_explanation: The decrease in spending is primarily due to differences between forecasted royalty transfers and actual royalty transfers recorded. This difference between the forecasted and the actual figure is the result of fluctuations in the prices of oil, changes in production, the timing of sales, forfeitures, as well as actual Corporate Income Tax (CIT) transfers versus forecasted CIT transfers.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness

The decrease is also attributable to the maturation of the funding requested to eliminate the Memorial Grant Program (MGP) backlog and accommodate projected near-term growth in program applications . The decrease in planned FTEs from FY 2025 to 2026 to FY 2026 to 2027 is primarily attributable to the maturation of the operating funding for the Initiative to Take Action Against Gun and Gang Violence (ITAAGGV) and the funding related to enhancing Canada’s firearm control framework under the compensation program for prohibited assault-style firearms.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding from FY 2024 to 2025 to FY 2025 to 2026 is primarily attributable to a decrease in funding levels for the First Nation and Inuit Policing Facilities Program (FNIPFP) and the First Nations and Inuit Policing Program (FNIPP). Funding levels are constantly being monitored to ensure that needs are properly supported. The decrease in planned FTEs from FY 2025 to 2026 to FY 2026 to 2027 is primarily attributable to the maturation of funding for the co-development of First Nations policing legislation and engagement to support Indigenous policing under the First Nations and Inuit Policing Program (FNIPP).
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2024-25 is primarily due to the annual transfer to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police through the Supplementary Estimates for the First Nations Community Policing Service. Additionally, some First Nations police services concluded too close to year-end to allow for the timely disbursement of stabilization and wage parity funds. Furthermore, a portion of the variance is attributable to infrastructure project delays, outdated funding caps, and provincial approval challenges. The intention is to transfer the lapsed funding for use in future fiscal years.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
planning_explanation:
The decrease in funding and FTEs over the next fiscal years can be explained by several factors.

1 - The repayable contribution reinvestment mechanism is currently being revised and its authorizations are not included in this Ministerial Plan for the fiscal year 2026-2027.

2 - For fiscal years 2024-2025 and 2025-2026, a reallocation of funds from grants and contributions to the operating budget was carried out in order to stabilize the workforce to ensure follow-ups and other essential activities to close the many emergency and recovery initiatives put in place in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

3 - The effort deployed by the ministry to refocus government spending on main priorities increases annually and results in further reductions in operating expenses.

4 - The Tourism Growth Program, a temporary initiative aimed at helping communities, small and medium-sized businesses and non-profit organizations create local and community tourism projects and events, ends March 31st.

core_responsibility: Adjudication of immigration and refugee cases
planning_explanation: The expected downward trend is attributable to the sunsetting of temporary funding.
variance_explanation:
The increase in spending for the 2024 to 2025 fiscal year is primarily attributed to the record-high number of refugee protection claims finalized, marking the highest volume in the Board’s history. This reflects the sustained and growing demand for asylum adjudication services.

In response, the Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB) has prioritized the allocation of resources to the Refugee Protection Division, and resources supporting the Division, under the IRB’s core responsibility of Adjudication of Immigration and Refugee Cases.

These efforts are part of a broader strategy to expand processing capacity and reduce wait times for refugee protection claimants. The IRB remains committed to delivering fair, timely, and efficient access to Canada’s asylum system.

Details to be found in the Departmental Results Report.

core_responsibility: Adjudication of immigration and refugee cases
planning_explanation: The expected downward trend is attributable to the sunsetting of temporary funding.

core_responsibility: Adjudication of immigration and refugee cases
variance_explanation:
The Immigration Division experienced a significant increase in both the volume and complexity of admissibility hearings. These proceedings generally take longer to complete and often require enhanced support services such as interpretation and transcription, services that became more costly due to rising demand and increased rates. To manage these pressures, the Board reallocated funds internally throughout the year. At the same time, the Immigration Division experienced a decrease in detention review intake.

Details to be found in the Departmental Results Report.

core_responsibility: Adjudication of immigration and refugee cases

variance_explanation:
In response to the increase in refugee protection claims and admissibility hearings, the Board mobilized additional resources to maintain operational efficiency. This included reallocating internal resources to high-demand areas and investing in digital tools and IT system upgrades. These improvements focused on enhancing security, strengthening compliance and enabling faster, more reliable decision-making.

The Board also advanced its information management strategy to better safeguard and leverage data, an important step in modernizing service delivery.

Higher-than-anticipated spending was largely driven by the hiring of specialized personnel needed to support key modernization initiatives aimed at improving the Board’s overall efficiency and responsiveness.

Details to be found in the Departmental Results Report.

The variance in actual and planned spending is primarily due to the revised 2024-25 methodology for aligning and reporting resources on core responsibilities and internal services to better align spending and human resources to areas of program activities. These reallocations were implemented to more directly support priority program activities, ensuring that resources are aligned with the organization’s evolving needs and that they enhance overall program effectiveness. This revised methodology is reflected in the increase in actual program spending, and in a decrease in actual internal services spending, compared to planned spending. This methodology was not anticipated during the planning phase.

planning_explanation: Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for delivering ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources. Reflected in 2024-25 are planned resources for new initiatives from Budget 2023, including the Canadian Dental Care Plan, Building a World-class Health Data System for Canadians and the Action Plan for Official Languages. Funding related to the Canadian Dental Care Plan for 2025-26 has not been secured yet; therefore, it is not reflected in outer years. Funding for cloud operations for 2025-26 is not included in the planned spending because the enterprise-wide funding model is being developed. In the absence of an enterprise-wide funding model by 2025-26, funding will be sourced by Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat resources for that year.

Resources will begin to ramp up and will peak in 2026-27, when the 2026 Census of Population and 2026 Census of Agriculture are conducted. This pattern is typical for the agency because of the cyclical nature of the Census Program.

variance_explanation: The net spending for this program is related to non-respendable items such as the Employee Benefit Plan (EBP).  An increase in resources for additional cost recovery work contributed to the increase in spending.

variance_explanation: The predictability of legal services expenditures is limited by their ad hoc incurrence, which poses challenges to forecast planned spending. Additionally, Statistics Canada does not have full-time equivalents in legal services as all associated costs are non-salary.
The spending variance is mainly the result of additional investments to accessibility and language training initiatives.

The spending variance is mainly the result of investments in information technology equipment replacement, driven by lifecycle renewal requirements, to ensure employees across the country are equipped to support program delivery.
The spending variance is mainly the result of additional investments to modernize Statistics Canada’s offices across the country.
The increase in planned spending for the Oversight and Treasury Board Support program is mainly attributable to internal reallocations.

program_name: Expenditure Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews
planning_explanation:
The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Expenditures Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews program is mainly attributable to the funding for damages caused by the Phoenix Pay System, which is sunsetting in 2025–26. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.

The decrease of full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2026–27 is mainly attributable to the decrease in funding for implementing proactive pay equity in the federal public service, which is sunsetting in 2024–25. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending for the Expenditures Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews program is mainly attributable to the transfer of central vote funding to other government departments and agencies.

program_name: Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives
variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending for the Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives program is mainly attributable to funding for the Strategic Communications and Ministerial Affairs sector to support the Communications Community Office.

planning_explanation: The increase of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Public Service Accessibility program is mainly attributable to a reallocation of resources.
variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending and full time equivalents for the Public Service Accessibility program is mainly attributed to funding for the renewal of the Office for Public Service Accessibility.

planning_explanation:
The increase of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Comptrollership program is mainly attributable to funding to advance clean fuels markets and carbon capture, utilization, and storage technologies in Canada and a reduction in transfers to various organizations to support projects which will reduce greenhouse gas emissions in federal government operations.

The decrease of full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2026–27 is mainly attributable to the decrease in funding from the National Research Council of Canada to TBS for the implementation of a buy clean secretariat for federal procurement (sunsetting in 2025–26), funding for the federal contaminated sites action plan (sunsetting in 2024–25), and funding to increase opportunities in federal procurement for Indigenous-led businesses (sunsetting in 2024–25). All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending for the Comptrollership Program is mainly attributable to funding for the Greening Government Fund for low carbon fuels and reduced carbon emissions initiatives that is either transferred to other government departments or lapsed at year end.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Digital Government program is mainly attributable to funding to provide continued leadership in cloud governance to help departments in their transition to cloud technologies, which is sunsetting in 2024–25. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending and full time equivalents for the Digital Government program is mainly attributable to funding for the strengthening of Canada’s access to information system, and funding to support the Government of Canada’s Enterprise Cyber Security Strategy.

planning_explanation: The increase of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Public Service Employer Payments program is mainly attributable to the funding requirements for the public service insurance plans and programs.
variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending for the Public Service Employer Payments program is mainly attributable to a $6,425 million increase in Public Service Pension Plan contributions that addressed an actuarial shortfall under the public service superannuation account in accordance with the Actuarial Report (20th) on the Pension Plan for the Public Service of Canada as at 31 March 2023 and additional funding for public service insurance plans and programs.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Employer program is mainly attributable to the decrease in funding for implementing proactive pay equity in the federal public service (sunsetting in 2024–25) and funding for the action plan for Black public servants (sunsetting in 2026–27). All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending for the Employer program is mainly attributable to the Implementing Proactive Pay Equity in the Federal Public Service reprofile.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2025–26 for the Regulatory Policy, Oversight, and Cooperation program is mainly attributable to the reduction in funding for the extension of targeted regulatory reviews and external advisory committee on regulatory competitiveness, which is sunsetting in 2024–25. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending for the Regulatory Policy, Oversight, and Cooperation program is mainly attributable to reduced spending in the Regulatory Affairs Sector.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Management and Oversight Services program is mainly attributable to budget reductions.
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full time equivalents for the Management and Oversight Services program is mainly attributable to minor vacancies in various program sectors.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Communications program is mainly attributable to the decrease in funding for the extension of targeted regulatory reviews, external advisory committee on regulatory competitiveness and the regulators’ capacity fund, and funding to address workplace harassment, discrimination and violence in the federal public service, which all sunset in 2024–25. All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending and full time equivalents for the Communications Services program is mainly attributable to funding for corporate costs stemming from new initiatives.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2025–26 for the Legal Services program is mainly attributable to the reduction in funding to address workplace harassment, discrimination and violence in the federal public service and funding for implementing proactive pay equity in the federal public service, which both sunset in 2024–25. All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending for the Legal Services program is mainly attributable to legal services payments.
The increase in planned spending for the Human Resources Management Services program is mainly attributable to funding for corporate costs stemming from new initiatives.

planning_explanation: The increase of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Financial Management Services program is attributable to funding for collective agreements.
variance_explanation: Minor Variance

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Information Management Services program is mainly attributable to decreased funding for implementing proactive pay equity in the federal public service (sunsetting in 2024–25) and funding for the action plan for Black public servants (sunsetting in 2025–26). All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full time equivalents for the Information Management Services program is mainly attributable to internal reallocations.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Information Technology Services program is mainly attributable to budget reductions.
variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending and full time equivalents for the Information Technology Services program is mainly attributable to the Corporate Services Sector, Information Management and Technology Directorate, for client service delivery, and applications.

The increase in planned spending and full time equivalents for the Real Property Management Services program is mainly attributable to spending on security, and the management of facilities and asset.
The decrease in planned spending for the Materiel Management Services program is mainly attributable to internal reallocations.
The increase in planned spending for the Acquisition Management Services program is mainly attributable to internal reallocations.

planning_explanation:
Planned spending for appeals is expected to increase due to funding received to address increased demand for review and appeal services. 

Planned human resources for appeals are expected to increase due to funding received to address increased demand for review and appeal services.

organization: Secretariat of the National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians
core_responsibility: Parliamentary Review of National Security and Intelligence Activities
variance_explanation: The Secretariat’s funding profile remains relatively consistent on a yearly basis. Year over year variances are primarily due to fluctuations in hospitality costs for Committee meetings, travel, sitting periods, Secretariat staff and Committee membership.

organization: Secretariat of the National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians
variance_explanation: The Secretariat’s funding profile remains relatively consistent on a yearly basis. Year over year variances are primarily due to fluctuations in hospitality costs for Committee meetings, travel, sitting periods, Secretariat staff and Committee membership.

program_name: Public Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect: 
* a net decrease in funding for the Indigenous Early Learning and Child Care Transformation Initiative, including transfers with the Department of Employment and Social Development.

FTE: 
The variance in FTEs primarily reflect : 
* the sunsetting of Budget 2021 funding for Mental Health and Wellness and funding to implement the Federal framework to address the legacy of residential schools and Anti-Indigenous Racism, as well as an allocation of resources from this program to meet program needs and priorities.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
 - mental wellness and substance use treatment services (Budget 2024); 
 - costs related to compensation settlement. 

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities; 

• the deferral of funding to future years which is mainly for costs related to compensation settlement.

These funds could not be spent in 2024-25 and are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for the Assisted Living Program.
variance_explanation: The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the Home and Community Care Program.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect: 
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for primary care (Budget 2021).

FTE:
* The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 is mainly due to funding received under Budget 2022 for Human Health Resources.
* The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 is mainly due to the sunsetting of Budget 2021.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
  - medical travel costs in Nunavut and Northwest Territories; and 
  - a mercury care home for Asubpeeschoseewagong Netum Anishinabek and a mercury wellness centre for Wabaseemoong Independent Nations. 

•  the deferral of funding to future years for a mercury wellness centre for Wabaseemoong Independent Nations. These funds are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* net decrease in funding associated with the First Nations Health Authority.
variance_explanation: The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the Indigenous Health Equity Fund.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* an increase in funding due to an internal transfer for the First Nations Health Authority in 2024-25.
variance_explanation: The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the Non-Insured Health Benefits Program (Budget 2024).

program_name: Jordan's Principle and the Inuit Child First Initiative
planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* decrease in funding for the continued implementation of Jordan's Principle and Inuit Child First Initiative.

FTE:
The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 in FTE utilization is mainly due to the sunset in Program Integrity piece of Funding for continued Implementation of Jordan's Principle (Budget 2023).
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the continued implementation of Jordan’s Principle; and 

•  the deferral of funding to future years for:
 -  the continued implementation of Jordan’s Principle;
 -  costs related to compensation and for the reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle; and 
 -  the continued implementation of the Inuit Child First Initiative (Budget 2024).
 
These funds could not be spent in 2024-25 and are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for the Pathways to Safe Indigenous Communities Initiative (Budget 2021). 

FTE:
The variance in FTEs is due to sunset of funding to support Indigenous policing and community safety.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the Family Violence Prevention Program (Budget 2024); and

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for implementation reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services Program.

FTE:
The variance is due to the sunset of :
* Funding to advance implementation of _An Act respecting First Nations, Inuit and Métis children, youth and families_, including a new grant program (at the end of 2024-25).
* Funding to implement the Cowessess First Nation’s child and family services law, “Miyo Pimatisowin Act” and, Funding to implement _An Act respecting First Nations, Inuit and Métis children, youth and families_ (at the end of 2024-25).
* Funding to support the implementation of the _Act respecting First Nations, Inuit and Métis children, youth and families_ and ongoing reform of Indigenous Child and Family Services (at the end of 2024-25).
* Funding for First Nations Child and Family Services; Canadian Human Rights Tribunal Orders Implementation; and Non-compliance Motion Settlement (at the end of 2025-26).
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
 - maintaining and advancing the reform of the First Nations Child and Family Services Program;  
 - advancing the implementation and operationalization of Indigenous children and family services’ laws; and 
 - costs related to compensation and for the reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services program and Jordan’s Principle. 

• unused funds at year-end that will return to the fiscal framework mainly for:  
 - the First Nations Child and Family Services program; and 
 - the delayed implementation and operationalization of Indigenous children and family servicesʼ laws. 

•  the deferral of funding to future years for:
 - advancing the implementation and operationalization of Indigenous children and family services' laws; 
 - costs related to compensation settlement; and 
 - reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services program.

These funds could not be spent in 2024-25 and are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* annual growth;
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to strengthen employment and skills for youth; and
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for income assistance, case management, and pre-employment supports to individuals and family living on reserve.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the On-Reserve Income Assistance Program (Budget 2024); and

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for urban, rural, and northern Indigenous housing projects (Budget 2022 and Budget 2023); 
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for the Urban Programming for Indigenous Peoples Program; and
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding fo infrastructure in Indigenous communities (Budget 2021).

FTE:
Significant reduction in FTEs after 2024-25 is due to:
* sunsetting Infrastructure Funding for Urban Programming for Indigenous Peoples Service Providers (Budget 2019);
* Funding for Indigenous infrastructure projects (Budget 2021); and 
* Funding Urban Programming for Indigenous Peoples (Budget 2022).
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
 - implementing the Urban, Rural and Northern Indigenous Housing Strategy (Budget 2023)
 - Urban Programming for Indigenous Peoples (Budget 2024). 
 
• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* annual growth; and
* an increase in funding for the core funding refinements of elementary and secondary education (Budget 2021).
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
•  an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
 - the First Nations Elementary and Secondary Education Program (Budget 2024); and 
 - establishing a National School Food Program (Budget 2024).

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities and some internal transfers.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to strengthen employment and skills for youth;
* annual growth; and 
* an increase in funding to support First Nations, Inuit and Métis Nation post-secondary students and to develop regional post-secondary strategies for First Nations (Budget 2019).

FTE:
The reduction of 9 FTEs in 2025-26 versus 2024-25 is mainly due to the sunsetting of the Funding to strengthen employment and skills supports for youth.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for supporting First Nations post-secondary students (Budget 2024); and 

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect the one-time investment in the Northern Ontario Grid Connection Project.

FTE:
The variance between 2024-25 to 2026-27 is due to sunsetting of Budget 2021 and 2022 Fall Economic Statements.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
 - the First Nations Water and Wastewater Enhanced Program; 
 - reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services program; and 
 - infrastructure projects in Indigenous communities (Budget 2024). 

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.   

•  the deferral of funding to future years for initiatives, such as:
 - a mercury care home for Asubpeeschoseewagong Netum Anishinabek and a mercury wellness centre for Wabaseemoong Independent Nations;
 - the establishment of the First Nations Water Commission; and 
 - emergency management on reserve (Budget 2019). 
 
These funds are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* an increase in funding for infrastructure projects in Indigenous communities;
* an increase in funding for First Nations land management; and
* a transfer from the Department of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs for the Federal Contaminated Sites Action Plan in 2024-25.

FTE:
The variance between 2024-25 to 2025-26 is due to a decrease in FTEs due to the sunsetting of FTEs previously funded for Additions to Reserve Land for First Nations Economic Recovery (Budget 2021) and the Federal Contaminated Site Action Plan: Phase IV.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the transfer from the Department of Natural Resources for the Federal Contaminated Sites Action Plan.

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities. 

•  the deferral of funding to future years to implement the Upimee asta Aski Agreement. These funds could not be spent in 2024-25 and are expected to be reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to reimburse First Nations and emergency management service providers for on-reserve response and recovery activities.
variance_explanation: The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* a transfer from the Department of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs in 2024-25 and 2025-26 to help advance reconciliation and establish a new relationship with the Mohawks of Kahnawà:ke.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for supporting Indigenous participation in economically sustainable clean energy projects (Budget 2024); and

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding to increase federal procurement from Indigenous-led businesses.

FTEs:
The variance between 2024-25 to 2026-27 is due to sunsetting of FTEs previously funded for creating additional opportunities in federal procurement.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the Aboriginal Entrepreneurship Program and the Métis Capital Corporations (Budget 2024); and 

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to adjust the new fiscal relationship grant for inflation and population growth (Budget 2021); and
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to implement phase one of a transformational approach to Indigenous data (Budget 2021).

FTE:
The variance of FTEs is due to:
* sunset of Funding for Strengthening Governance and Advancing the New Fiscal Relationship with First Nations, and Enhancing Initiatives of the First Nations Financial Management Board.
* sunset of Funding to implement phase one of a transformational approach to Indigenous data.
* sunset of Funding to Implement the Expedited Resolution Strategy for Agricultural Benefits Claims.
variance_explanation:
The difference between 2024-25 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:
• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
 - supporting Indigenous governance and capacity (Budget 2024). 
 - Indian Act registration services (Budget 2024); 
 - advancing the new fiscal relationship with First Nations (Budget 2024); and 
 - adjusting the new fiscal relationship grant for inflation and population growth (Budget 2021). 

• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.

organization: Federal Economic Development Agency for Northern Ontario
variance_explanation: The variance is attributable the differences in the basis used for planning versus actual expense allocation. Planned amounts were determined using full-time equivalent (FTE) counts, which assumed a direct alignment of costs with program activities. However, as FedNor continues to rely on other departments for the provision of internal services through Memorandum of Understanding during its transition to becoming a standalone agency, many expenses have been appropriately coded to internal Services rather than being tied to program-specific FTEs.

planning_explanation:
The decrease in 2026-27 planned spending compared to 2025-26 reflects a decrease in funding for the Youth Employment and Skills Program. 

The decrease in 2027-28 planned spending compared to 2026-27 reflects the expiry of the Wine Sector Support Program at the end of 2026-27.

The decrease in 2026-27 planned spending compared to 2025-26 reflects a decrease in funding for the Dairy Direct Payment Program and the Poultry and Egg On-Farm Investment Program. This is offset by increased funding for the Dairy Innovation and Investment Fund.

The decrease in 2027-28 planned spending compared to 2026-27 reflects a decrease in funding for the Supply Management Processing Investment Fund and the Dairy Innovation and Investment Fund.

The Canadian Pari-Mutuel Agency's vote-netted revenue, operating costs and Employee Benefit Plan are being adjusted to reflect the forecasts in their 2025-26 to 2027-28 Business Plan. The revenues are generated through the regulation and supervision of pari-mutuel betting on horse racing at racetracks across Canada.

program_name: Federal, Provincial and Territorial Cost-shared Markets and Trade

planning_explanation:
The decrease in 2027-28 planned spending compared to 2026-27 reflects the expiry of the Local Food Infrastructure Fund at the end of 2026-27.

The decrease in full-time equivalents in 2027-28 compared to 2026-27 reflects the expiry of the Local Food Infrastructure Fund at the end of 2026-27.
The decrease in 2026-27 planned spending compared to 2025-26 is because 2025-26 reflects new funding to finalize the divestiture of three irrigation infrastructure projects and one dam.
The decrease in 2027-28 planned spending compared to 2026-27 reflects a decrease in funding for the Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (Sustainable CAP).

The decrease in 2026-27 planned spending compared to 2025-26 reflects spending savings under the refocusing government spending exercise. 

The decrease in 2027-28 planned spending compared to 2026-27 reflects a decrease in funding for the Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (Sustainable CAP).

The decrease in full-time equivalents in 2026-27 compared to 2025-26 reflects a reduction in support for the Agricultural Clean Technology Program.

The planned spending reflects the temporary additional funding received through Budget 2023; The 3-year funding, initiated in the fiscal year 2023–24, is set to culminate in 2025–26. This explains the decrease in fiscal years 2026–27 and 2027–28. CICS remains committed to ensuring minimal disruption to its core mandate. Efforts will be focused on sustaining critical functions, particularly those that directly support high-level intergovernmental meetings.

As a result of a proactive strategy, 5 temporary employees have been added over the past two fiscal years, closely aligned with the expanded budget covering a three-year period, from 2023–24 to 2025–26. Staffing levels in Conference Services will remain stable in 2025–26, with a target of approximately 30 employees. The additional full-time equivalents (FTEs) directly support CICS' mandate to provide technical and logistical assistance, as well as planning services, for federal-provincial-territorial and provincial-territorial conferences involving First Ministers, Ministers, and Deputy Ministers across Canada. By maintaining a steady staffing level through 2025–26, CICS is positioned to continue meeting the evolving demands of intergovernmental collaboration, while upholding the highest standards of service and support.

planning_explanation:
**($)**
The decrease in planned spending from 2025-26 to 2026-27 is mainly attributable to:
•	The temporary top-up funding for the Interim Federal Health Program ending in 2025-26 to manage asylum-related expenditures as the system continues to respond to elevated claim volumes;
•	The decrease in income support under the Resettlement Assistance Program to individuals affected by the crisis in Gaza; and
•	The decrease in resettlement funding through the 2023-2025 Immigration Levels Plan as a result of a decrease in Government Assisted Refugees admissions.

**FTE**
The decrease in planned FTEs from 2025-26 to 2027-28 is mainly attributable to:
•	The temporary personnel funding ending in 2026-27 related to Canada’s commitment to resettle Afghan refugees;
•	The decrease in personnel funding for permanent resident processing following the decision to reduce immigration levels as part of the 2025-2027 Immigration Levels Plan;
•	The decrease in temporary personnel funding for processing and resettlement activities related to Canada’s response to conflicts in Gaza and Ukraine; and
•	The department’s commitment to reduce spending as announced in Budget 2023 Refocusing Government Spending.

The increase in planned spending from 2026-27 to 2027-28 is mainly attributable to the increase in legal funding to pay for services provided by the Department of Justice, in particular for the anticipated increase in litigation relating to asylum decisions part of the stabilization and integrity of Canada’s asylum system.

**($)**

•	The department’s commitment to reduce spending as announced in Budget 2023 Refocusing Government Spending.

•	The temporary personnel funding ending in 2025-26 for the full Tranche 1 implementation of the Digital Platform Modernization Phase 3 programme, including the implementation of front-facing capabilities for all IRCC clients to improve client experience and streamline application intake; and 
•	The decrease of personnel funding for information management services following the decision to reduce immigration levels as part of the 2025-2027 Immigration Levels Plan.

**FTE**

Spending: Although there appears to be a decrease in spending starting in 2026–27, this is based on forecasts developed well in advance of the reporting period due to the nature of the budgeting process. More recent forecast models suggest an increase in demand for many programs and services in the coming years. Planned spending for 2026–27 and 2027–28 will be updated in future years to incorporate the latest projections, bringing them more in line with 2025–26 levels. Veterans' benefits remain unaffected.

FTEs: Funding was extended to the end of fiscal year 2025–26 for Service Excellence initiatives, which was originally part of the Government’s Economic and Fiscal Snapshot in August 2020. In addition to this initiative, we have also extended funding for 2 years (to the end of 2025–26) to maintain frontline staffing levels, including the Case Manager to Veteran ratio, and upgrade the tools Case Managers use – freeing up more time for them to work directly with Veterans. This funding will end after 2025–26 fiscal year. Case Management Renewal temporary funding begins in 2025–26 aimed at enhancing and modernizing case management services for Veterans until the end of 2026–27. While funding for human resource levels may return to reduced levels (from prior to Service Excellence and Case Management Renewal) in 2027–28, we will continue to reassess our long term capacity as we move forward in improving service to Veterans and their families.

Spending: The Department has temporary funding in place in 2025–26 to support research initiatives that contribute to the well-being of military members, Veterans and their families. The Department also has temporary funding in place for the expansion and enhancement of the Veterans and Family Well-Being fund until 2027–28.

More recent forecast models suggest an increase in demand for many programs and services in the coming years. Planned spending for 2026–27 and 2027–28 will be updated in future years to incorporate the latest projections, bringing them more in line with 2025–26 levels.

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
planning_explanation: The reduction in forecast expenditure for 2026-2027 is due in particular to the revision of the mechanism for reinvesting sums collected from repayable contributions to regular programmes, which until 2023-2024 provided a significant proportion of recurrent funding. A transitional measure makes it possible to maintain funding for the years 2024-2025 and 2025-2026. At the time of writing, no measures have been confirmed for subsequent years. The expenditure forecasts for 2026-2027 and 2027-2028 may therefore be adjusted depending on future budgetary decisions.

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
planning_explanation: The reduction in forecast expenditure for 2026-2027 is due in particular to the revision of the mechanism for reinvesting sums collected from repayable contributions to regular programmes, which until 2023-2024 provided a significant proportion of recurrent funding. A transitional measure makes it possible to maintain funding for the years 2024-2025 and 2025-2026. At the time of writing, no measures have been confirmed for subsequent years. The expenditure forecasts for 2026-2027 and 2027-2028 may therefore be adjusted depending on future budgetary decisions.

The planned spending figures for 2025–26 and 2026–27 reflect the gradual phasing out of temporary funding received in previous fiscal years. Fiscal year 2025–26 represents the last full year of temporary funding, leading to a slight reduction in planned spending for 2026–27 as funding begins to wind down. By 2027–28, planned spending is reduced to align with the Committee’s permanent reference levels. However, the planned spending amount is significantly higher than previous years due to reprofiled funding from previous fiscal years, which is been carried forward to address the costs related for the workplace colocation project.

The planned FTEs for the next three fiscal years align with the temporary funding received from the Department of National Defence. This temporary funding supports workforce needs through 2025–26 and 2026–27, with a slight reduction beginning in 2027–28 as FTE levels return to align with the organization’s baseline budget.

The planned spending figures for 2027-28 is significantly higher than previous years due to reprofiled funding from previous fiscal years, which is been carried forward to address the costs related for the workplace colocation project.  

The planned FTEs for the next three fiscal years align with the temporary funding received from the Department of National Defence, and will gradually return in 2027-28 to levels consistent with the organization’s baseline budget.

planning_explanation:
The ERC’s data specific to Internal Services was segregated and became available in 2023-24; therefore, for 2022-23 actual full-time equivalents (FTE) are presented for ERC as a whole. 
Aligned with its set results in the 2020-21 approved Program Integrity ask, the ERC had increased its FTE in 2022-23 and 2023-24. Nevertheless, due to the limited funding and compensation reserve received for recent economic increases, the ERC has had to decrease its staff complement demonstrated in the above table. The enforced FTE adjustments due to budgetary pressures may impact the ERC’s capability to deliver on the established results and targets.

program_name: Expenditure Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews
planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Expenditures Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews program is mainly attributable to specific funding for administering human resources and pay for the federal public service, which is sunsetting in 2026–27. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.

program_name: Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Public Service Accessibility program is mainly attributable to the sunsetting of funding for the renewal of the Office for Public Service Accessibility in 2025–26. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.

The increase of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Comptrollership program is mainly attributable to funding transfers from various organizations to the Treasury Board Secretariat for contributions to the Greening Government Fund.

The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Digital Government program is mainly attributable to the sunsetting of funding to support the Government of Canada’s Enterprise Cyber Security Strategy in 2026–27. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.

The increase of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Public Service Employer Payments program is mainly attributable to the funding requirements for the Public Service Insurance plans and programs.

The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Employer program is mainly attributable to the decreases in funding for administering human resources and pay for the federal public service (sunsetting in 2026–27), funding for the Action Plan for Black Public Servants (sunsetting in 2026–27) and funding for implementing proactive pay equity in the federal public service (sunsetting in 2025–26). All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.

The increase of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Regulatory Policy, Oversight, and Cooperation program is mainly attributable to the reduction in transfers from Treasury Board Secretariat to various organizations for Regulatory Experimentation Projects.
The decrease of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Management and Oversight Services program is mainly attributable to the Responsible Government Spending Phase 1 initiative.

The decrease of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Communications program is mainly attributable to the sunsetting of funding for administering human resources and pay for the federal public service in 2026–27. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.

The decrease of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Legal Services program is mainly attributable to the sunsetting of funding to support the implementation of an Act for the Substantive Equality of Canada’s Official Languages. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.

The decrease of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Human Resources Management Services program is mainly attributable to the sunsetting of funding for administering human resources and pay for the federal public service. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.
The increase of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Financial Management Services program is mainly attributable to funding for collective agreements.

The decrease of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Information Management Services program is mainly attributable to the sunsetting of funding for administering human resources and pay for the federal public service (sunsetting in 2026–27) and funding for the Action Plan for Black Public Servants (sunsetting in 2026–27). All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
The decrease of planned spending from 2025–26 to 2027–28 for the Information Technology Services program is mainly attributable to the Responsible Government Spending Phase 1 initiative.

Planned human resources for appeals is expected to remain the same in 2025–26 for review and appeal services.
The subsequent decrease in human resources in 2026-27 and 2027-28 reflects the winding down of temporary funding previously received through Budget 2023.

program_name: Public Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect: 
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of time limited funding for mental wellness and substance use treatment services (Budget 2024);
* transfers with the Department of Employment and Social Development for the Indigenous Early Learning and Child Care Transformation Initiative in 2025-26; and
* sunset (at the end of 2026-27) of funding for health human resources.

FTE:
The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 is due to:
* Sunsetting of Funding to Sustain Support for Mental Wellness and Substance Use Treatment Services.  
The variance between 2026-27 and 2027-28 is due to: 
* Sunsetting of Funding for Health Human Resources.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect: 
•  sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for the Assisted Living program.

FTE: 
Slight decrease from 2025-26 to 2026-27 for Assisted Living program is due to the sunsetting funds from the Budget 2022 off-cycle.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for primary care (Budget 2021).

FTE:
The variance between 2025-26 to 2027-28 is due to:
* sunsetting of Budget 2021 and funding for Health Human Resources,   
* reductions related to the first Refocusing Government Spending.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* an increase in funding associated with the First Nations Health Authority, including internal transfers.

FTE: Not applicable

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for the Non-Insured Health Benefits Program; and
* an increase in funding due to the Non-Insured Health Benefits Program (Budget 2024). 

FTE: Not applicable

program_name: Jordan's Principle and the Inuit Child First Initiative
planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* Jordan’s Principle returning to Budget 2022 funding level upon expiry of additional temporary funding sources on March 31st, 2026.

FTE: 
The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 is due to: 
• sunset of Funding for the Continued Implementation of the Inuit Child First Initiative; 
• sunsetting of the program integrity funding for the Continued Implementation of Jordan’s Principle.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for the Pathways to Safe Indigenous Communities Initiative (Budget 2021 and Budget 2023); and
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for the Family Violence Prevention Program (Budget 2024).

FTE: 
The variance in FTEs is due to sunset of funding to support Indigenous policing and community safety.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* the reduction in funding for an _Act respecting First Nations, Inuit and Métis children, youth and families_.

FTE: 
The year-over-year variance observed on the FTE side is mainly due to recently found operational efficiencies in the delivery of the First Nations Child and Family Services Program as it continues to pursue Long Term Reform.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* annual growth;
* a decrease in funding for the On-Reserve Income Assistance Program (Budget 2024); and
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding to adjust the new fiscal relationship grant for inflation and population growth (Budget 2021).

FTE: Not applicable

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) for Indigenous urban infrastructure and housing (Budget 2023); and
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) for Funding for Urban Programming for Indigenous Peoples (Budget 2024).

FTE: 
Decrease of 9 FTEs is the result of sunsetting funds from Budget 2019, Budget 2021 and Budget 2022 off-cycle decisions.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) for the First Nations Elementary and Secondary Education Program (Budget 2024); 
* sunset (at the end of 2026-27) to advance adult education for First Nations (Budget 2024), including a transfer to CIRNAC in 2025-26 and 2026-27;
* sunset (at the end of 2026-27)  for the implementation of the regional education agreement with the First Nations Education Council in Quebec (Budget 2022); 
* an increase in funding for the core funding refinements of elementary and secondary education (Budget 2021) and 
* annual growth.


FTE:
The reduction of 28 FTEs in 2026-27 compared to 2025-26 is primarily attributed to:
* Sunsetting of Vote 1 for the First Nations Elementary and Secondary Education Program Integrity announced in Budget 2024
* Sunsetting of Vote 1 for the Enhancement of the First Nations Elementary and Secondary Education on Reserve announced in Budget 2021.
The reduction of 11 FTEs in 2027-28 compared to 2026-27 is mainly due to : 
* Sunsetting of Vote 1 for Advance First Nations Lifelong Learning: Adult Education announced in Budget 2021
* Sunsetting of Vote 1 funding to support the implementation of the Regional Education Agreement with the First Nations Education Council in Quebec announced in Budget 2022

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2026-27) of funding to support First Nations post-secondary students (Budget 2024);
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding to support First Nations and Inuits Youth Employment Strategy (Budget 2024); and 
* annual growth.

FTE:
The reduction of 9 FTEs in 2026-27 compared to 2025-26 is mainly due to the sunsetting of the funding to strengthen employment and skills supports for youth.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2026-27) of funding for infrastructure projects related to housing (Budget 2022), education facilities (Budget 2024)and health facilities (Budget 2024) in Indigenous communities; 
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for the First Nations Water and Wastewater Enhanced Program and the establishment of the First Nations Water Commission; and
* a net increase in funding for the Weeneebayko Area Health Authority. 

FTE:
Variance between 2025-26 to 2026-27:
Decrease in FTEs is mainly due to the sunsetting of FTEs previously funded for the First Nations Water and Wastewater Enhanced Program (FES 2023)

Variance between 2026-27 to 2027-28:
Decrease in FTEs is mainly due to the sunsetting of FTEs previously funded for infrastructure projects in indigenous communities related to education facilities (Budget 2024) and to housing (Budget 2022)

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for First Nations emergency management.

FTE: Not applicable

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2026-27) of funding to support Indigenous-led economic recovery and stimulus for communities, businesses and the tourism industry (Budget 2022); and
* sunset (at the end of 2026-27) of funding to support Indigenous participation in economically sustainable clean energy projects (Budget 2024).  

FTE:
The variance in FTEs between 2026-27 to 2027-28 is due to:
* sunsetting of FTEs previously funded to support Indigenous-led economic recovery and stimulus for communities, businesses and the tourism industry (Budget 2022) and to support Indigenous participation in economically sustainable clean energy projects (Budget 2024).

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* an increase in funding for the Aboriginal Entrepreneurship Program and the Métis Capital Corporations (Budget 2024); 
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding to support the Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada; and
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding to increase federal procurement from Indigenous-led businesses.

FTE:
The variance in FTEs between 2025-26 to 2026-27 is due to:
* sunsetting of FTEs previously funded to increase opportunities in Federal procurement for Indigenous-Led Businesses.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding to support Indigenous governance and capacity (Budget 2024); and
* sunset (at the end of 2026-27) of funding to support community development for First Nations. 

FTE:
The variance in FTE is mainly due to:
* sunset of funding to support community development for First Nations;
* sunset of funding to Support the New Fiscal Relationship Grant and Expand Eligibility for the Grant; and
* sunset of Funding to implement phase one of a transformational approach to Indigenous data.
